column2: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (UP)--The Chicago Cubs extended their season's longest winning streak to six games tonight as they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4--3, to sweep the three--game series and put the Redbirds two and a half games behind the Milwaukee Braves.
A scientific break-through described as "probably the greatest single advance in radar" since 1939 was announced yesterday.
GENEVA, Aug. 8--Science is confronted with the possibility of failure in the fight against insect-borne diseases, the World Health Organization said today.
With the approach of the hurricane season the Automobile Club of New York sounds a warning that should be heeded by automobilists. Normally, if a hurricane is approach-...

Record sales and earnings for any half year were reported yesterday by the General Dynamics Corporation for the first six months of this year. Frank Pace Jr., president, predicted that this year's results would substantially exceed the record sales and earnings of last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)-- The Senate passed today an $884,151,323 public works appropriations bill. The vote was 85 to 1.

ARMY men from the United States Military Academy were caught in a huddle with agents of a Western power in Philadelphia recently and it's no disclosure of classified information to reveal what went on. All that need be told is that the said agents were from South Bend, Ind., and the secret is out.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8--The contract bridge team led by John R. Crawford of Philadelphia came from behind tonight to capture the 1957 Masters Team of Four and United States Championship.
Two town houses on upper Fifth Avenue soon will make way for a modern apartment building.
A Yonkers Raceway spokesman declared yesterday that ownership of track stock by persons with police records did not endanger racing if the ownership had no impact on the track's management.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--A Senate-House conference agreed today on a $3,366,000,000 foreign aid authorization bill, $498,410,000 below the amount asked by President Eisenhower.
WARSAW, Aug. 8--The first atomic maneuvers of the Polish Army and certainly the first recorded in the press of Iron Curtain countries have been described in the newspaper Glos Pracy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today condemned the Arab economic boycott against Israel as a "deadweight" on United Nations efforts for a settlement in the Middle East.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 8 (AP) --A tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico continued tonight a steady building of force. The Weather Bureau predicted it "will probably reach hurricane force late tonight or early Friday."

Terms of a merger between Indian Head Mills, Inc., and J.L. Stifel Sons, Inc., textile manufacturing companies, have been approved by directors of both companies. Special meetings of stockholders of both companies to vote on the merger have been called for Sept. 12.

The Dodgers, who still have pennant hopes, were subjected to a 12-3 setback at Ebbets Field last night. (Los Angeles papers please copy.) The team that inflicted the season's heaviest drubbing on the Brooks was the Giants, who long ago stopped hoping. (San Francisco papers please copy.)
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 8 --Miss Joan Ryder and Albert Arthur Tileny Wickersham will be married in the autumn.

Terms of a merger between Indian Head Mills, Inc., and J.L. Stifel Sons, Inc., textile manufacturing companies, have been approved by directors of both companies. Special meetings of stockholders of both companies to vote on the merger have been called for Sept. 12.

The Dodgers, who still have pennant hopes, were subjected to a 12-3 setback at Ebbets Field last night. (Los Angeles papers please copy.) The team that inflicted the season's heaviest drubbing on the Brooks was the Giants, who long ago stopped hoping. (San Francisco papers please copy.)
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 8 --Miss Joan Ryder and Albert Arthur Tileny Wickersham will be married in the autumn.
Ignored by his country, Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel of the Soviet secret police vas arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court. He appeared without friend or even counsel.

There is good news from India. Eight hours before a strike-call deadline the postal, telegraph and telephone employes' union, whose ramifications are nation-wide, called off its action. The strike would have brought paralysis to ...

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP)--Milwaukee tonight moved to the biggest lead in the National League this season, three and one-half games, as Bob Buhl, backed by an eighteen-hit attack, subdued the second-place St. Louis Cardinals, 13--2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP)-- Nearly all of the twenty-two major oil importing companies have agreed to cooperate with President Eisenhower's program for voluntary reduction in the flow of foreign oil into the United States, it was announced today.
Bankers were warned yesterday to step up the efficiency of their automobile dealer, financing programs to head off mounting losses.

Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel shows every indication of having concealed his alleged spy role with utmost deception and a degree of friendliness and consideration that has left his acquaintances baffled.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 --Paul Newman, on loan from Warner Brothers, and Anthony Franciosa, under contract to Twentieth Century-Fox, will be teamed in the Jerry Wald production of "The Long Hot Summer."
MOSCOW, Aug. 9--About fifty of the Americans attending the Moscow Youth Festival were planning tonight to defy the State Department's ban on travel to Communist China.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 9--Bismarck, who made of Germany a great world force, is known to history as the Iron Chancellor. His was a great intellect. Gifts of expression ranked him high among writers. He was a diplomat who knew much of the outside world.
A NEW YORKER, making an inventory of her spice shelf, realized that some of the items had been there for more than a year. She would like to know just how long spices can be kept.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9-- There were upheavals in the corrected-time placings on the New York Yacht Club cruise run from Block Island today. Strongly entrenched previous winners, notably C. Raymond Hunt's Harrier, fell behind and two new names appeared on top in their divisions.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company this year had the highest earnings for a first half in its history, according to the semi-annual resuits announced yesterday.
Following is a list of the city's Boards of Elections and their branch offices at which voters may register and enroll under the new system of permanent personal registration.

Rear Admiral Milton E. Miles, commandant of the Third Naval District, who was responsible for training Chinese guerrillas in World War II, said here yesterday that those Chinese were "all waiting to fight."
Film, once the baby of the plastics family, has become an adult.
Ambassadorial life was pictured yesterday as a strenuous life rather than one of ease, excessive holidaying and the pursuit of pleasure.
Deadly accuracy with irons and excellent putting are what Charles Conrad hopes will carry him to a division title in the National Amputee Golf Association tournament next week.

CINCINNATI, Saturday, Aug. 10 (AP)--A four-run uprising on five hits in the eighth inning carried Cincinnati's Redlegs to a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs early today to complete a double-header sweep.

Philip Barnet Bucky, Professor of Mining at Columbia University and inventor of a device to determine the force of gravity, died Thursday after an operation in St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 58. He had a heart ailment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP)--Nellie Fox kept alive Chicago's pennant hopes today when he twice drove in the tying run and then pounded home in the eleventh inning on Larry Doby's single for a 5-4 White Sox victory over the Detroit Tigers.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 9 --Dr. Frederick George Novy, a noted American bacteriologist, died at his home here yesterday. He was 92 years old.
TOKYO, Aug. 9 (Reuters)-- Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama said here today he was greatly concerned about the recent revival of moves in the United States to curtail imports of Japanese products.

"NORTH OF MARKET,"* by Arthur Foff, is an offbeat, impressionistic novel of San Fransisco. Its characters are rather Steinbeckian. They drift with a kind of bustling indolence through fogs and sunlight and darkness in pursuit of raffish, unattainable ideals. The whole thing doesn't add up to anything in particular, but I enjoyed it because it is written by a man who really knows the life of one of the most beguiling towns on this continent.

Unhappy motorists fumed while their overheated cars steamed in a three-hour tie-up yesterday on the Grand Central Parkway extension at Northern Boulevard in Queens. The tie-up was made worse by the necessity of towing away overheated cars.

A couple of early 3's sufficed to give Ray Crone and the Giants a 6-2 decision over the Phillies last night at the Polo Grounds. The fourth straight victory by Bill Rigney's apparently "Friscobound club" was viewed by only 6,247 fans.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP)--Sam Snead showed his heels to the awed younger pros today with a second-round 69 and a sizzling halfway total of 134 to maintain his lead in golf's biggest money tournament.
WARSAW, Aug. 9--Under a new Government decree most Poles will not be allowed to keep more than 15,000 zlotys of their earnings a month.

Lazarus Trommer, a retired civil engineer and a professional writer under the pen name of Elbert Aidline, died of a heart attack Thursday at his, home, 88-43 Seventy-fourth Avenue, Glendale, Queens, after several months' illness. He was 69 years old.
ROME, Aug. 9 (Reuters)-- Italy's two airlines, Alitalia and Linee Aeree Italiane (L.A.I.), have decided to join forces in a new line that will be known as Alitalia-Linee Aeree Italiane.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 9--Somebody must be tinkering with the track as the American League flag race churns up the backstretch. Expected to provide the Yankees with a clear course to another smashing pennant triumph, it sent the Bombers skidding again tonight as they dropped a 4-3 decision to Paul Richards' Orioles.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 9 --Miss Elizabeth Chandler White and Dr. William Newcome Christenson were married this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Robert Appleyard, the rector. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Tage Teisen.

Seven weeks ago last Thursday the United Nations made public the damning indictment returned against the Government of Russia by a special committee on the problem of Hungary. Members of this committee came from Denmark, Australia, Ceylon, Tunisia and Uruguay. They were a fair cross section of the free world with the great powers left out.

Stephen and Mary Virag sold the five-story apartment house at 2260 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, to Geisinger Germain, realty operators. The buyers resold the house containing twenty-seven suites to the 2260 Realty Corporation for investment. Joseph Panman Associates negotiated both transactions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- A subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities took measures today to protect a woman who said she expected reprisals for her testimony about Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The House of Representatives voted today $336,851,000 for the Atomic Energy Commission, but deleted from the bill a $55,000,000 Democratic program for Government construction of plants to provide atomic power.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and subsidiaries said in the June-quarterly report released yesterday that a number of its larger industrial customers were experiencing "a generally lower level of operation," thus reducing gas sales volume.

Richard R. Smith of West Rindge, N.H., one of the leaders in the development of the modern college textbook, died two weeks ago in Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, at the age of 71, it was learned yeserday.
William P. Murphy, former Chief City Fire Marshal, died yesterday in his home, 212 East 182d Street, the Bronx. His age was 69.

With the completion of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation's $100,000,000 borrowing on 5 per cent debentures this week, corporate financing will momentarily take a back seat in the new capital market.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Democratic policymakers held out hope today for broad tax revisions next year but backed away from any promise of tax relief.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9--Production by the Italian steel industry will increase 50 per cent by 1960, the United States representative of an Italian steel combine said here today.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9--Danny McDevitt met the Pirates for the first time in his life at Forbes Field tonight and helped the Dodgers to emerge with a 4-2 victory.
GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Aug. 9--Howling winds tore at three mountaineers inching their way toward safety tonight on the sheer north face of the Eiger Mountain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The State Department has been trying for Some time without success to solve a new Kremlin riddle.
An almost extinct art form-- Chinese finger painting--is being revived by the Department of Art of the Fordham University School of Education.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 9 --A delegate to the Lutheran World Conference on Social Responsibility criticized the Roman Catholic Church today for sponsoring such institutions as Father Flanagan's boys home, Boys Town, Neb.
The Willys-Overland Export Corporation has elected Sydney W. Taylor and L. Keith Covelle Jr. as vice presidents, it was announced yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 9-- A century-old dairy farm--one of the few remaining in lower Fairfield County--fell victim today to the onrushing suburbs.
BERLIN, Aug. 9--Nikita S. Khrushchev vowed today that the Soviet Union did not want war and that its leaders were convinced there would be long-lasting peace.

ROME, Aug. 8--The Vatican took a serious and most unsympathetic view today of an appeal to the Pope by a New Orleans association of Roman Catholic laymen against racial integration in their archdiocese.

In preparation for the new mutual security program the Senate and House committees concerned initiated at considerable expense twentyone separate official and private studies. All these studies agreed that in view of the continued threat of Communist aggression, and despite the $60 billion, including loans,
A tubeless portable radiophonograph combination that plays on four flashlight batteries is going into mass production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--Miss Irene Dunne, the film actress, was one of ten persons nominated by President Eisenhower today to represent the United States at the twelfth session of the United Nations General Assembly. The Assembly is scheduled to meet Sept. 17 at U.N. Headquarters in New York.
The eight foreign pupils suspected of having Asiatic influenza were reported by the Health Department yesterday to be doing "very well." They are expected to be fully recovered in two or three days.

A 19-year-old youth, said to have been fleeing a brawl in a Brooklyn bar, was shot by a detective last night. The youth was taken to Kings County Hospital, where he was reported in serious condition with a bullet in his back.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Congress was urged today to enact at least a minimal program to "liberalize" and "humanize" the present immigration laws before adjournment.
Wall Streeters insisted yesterday that they couldn't make a dollar for themselves or their customers.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9--The final week-end of concerts in the Music Shed at Tanglewood began with a program conducted by Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Shortly after World War II James Hopkins Smith Jr. decided to leave his home on the North Shore of Long Island and head for the open spaces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Speaker Sam Rayburn called on the House of Representatives today to concur in the Senate's version of the Administration's civil rights bill if it wished to obtain legislation at this session of Congress.
THREE firearms, two shotguns and a rifle, of inter est to hunters this fall have been put on the market recently. Any of them would be a good addition to a modest gun rack.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Roger M. Slough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, fenced for ninety minutes this morning with Senator Estes Kefauver on the price and the pricing of steel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--An antibiotic composition that is said to be highly effective against plant diseases caused by bacteria was patented this week by Dr. Kenneth B. Tate for Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., of Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Aug. 9 (AP)--A walkout of some 300 mailers at 6 o'clock tonight shut down six Boston daily newspapers in a dispute over wages.
Church leaders from twentynine countries will gather in Minneapolis Thursday for the eleven-day Third Assembly of the Lutheran World Federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug 9--Malcolm S. Forbes stepped into a curve ball last night on the issue of religious bias in the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign.
DUBLIN, Aug. 2--Ireland's historic diggings have been turning up treasures that make several of the country's excavations starred points on the archaeologist's travel itinerary.

The State of Missouri is planning th borrow $30,000,000 in the bond market on Sept. 17. The offering is the second under an authority to borrow $75,000,000 authorized by the voters last year for state penal, educational and mental institutions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The wholesale price index of primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 118.0 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Prices averaged higher for farm products and processed foods; but the index for all commodities other than farm and foods registered no change.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9-- Britain initiated today a move by nine European countries to have the Argentine Government abandon discriminatory maritime transport policies.

Effective action is at last promised against labor racketeers and unscrupulous employers who exploit New York workers through collusive union contracts. Within the last few days both organized labor and the city government have announced campaigns to put an end to these abuses, especially widespread among small firms employing Puerto Rican and Negro workers.

Just about a year ago the New York Stock Exchange reported that fifty-six of its listed stocks had been split two-forone during the first half of the year. This was a new high, exceeding the forty-seven issues split during the first six months of 1955.
TOKYO, Aug. 9--Charges of accidental manslaughter were filed by the police in Nakaminato yesterday against a United States Air Force lieutenant whose plane struck and killed a Japanese woman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The old United Auto Workers, A.F.L., paid Johnny Dio $16,000 to get rid of him in 1954, but two other officials got so much more in "severance pay" that they made Dio look like a small-time racketeer.

TORONTO, Aug. 9--A.V. Roe, Canada, Ltd., which in twelve years has become Canada's biggest industrial syndicate and its largest employer of labor, yesterday offered to pays as much as $130,000,000 for the giant Dominion steel and Coal Corporation.
Audie Murphy will make his television debut is the National Broadcasting Company's new "Suspicion" series.
Overdoses of vitamins and too much food for infants may become as serious a medical problem as malnutrition has been in the past, it appeared yesterday from a summary of scientific studies.
HAVANA, Aug. 9--Two encounters between rebels and Government troops, in which three rebels were killed, have occurred in Las Villas Province, according to Army headquarters at Camp Columbia here.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 9-- The Tennessee State Board of Education directed a subcommittee today to draft "with all deliberate speed" a new plan to desegregate the six colleges operated by the state.
The municipal Civil Service Commission has restored to their jobs three Transit Authority employes who had been dismissed for insubordination.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9--The oldpro New York Giants were too skilled of hand and foot and too rugged on defense for the youngpro--College All-Stars tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 (AP)-- Tropical storm Bertha, no longer a hurricane, lost some of its strength tonight and apparently would become even weaker as it continued to move over land in East Texas.
A former high ranking Cuban Army officer charged yesterday that the regime of President Fulgencio Batista had tortured and murdered many of its political opponents.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9-- Starting next Wednesday, there will be a nine-race program of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway every night until the meeting ends on Nov. 30.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 9--Gov. George M. Leader said today that the Joint Federal State Action Committee would consider the advisability of shifting to the states five programs on which the Federal Government was spending $400,000,000 annually.

An old and unusual art technique has been adapted by a young Israeli artist to create a huge mural in the modern passenger terminal now being completed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The six-month long fight for control of the Scranton Lace Company of Scranton, Pa., may soon be settled. Sol. M. Zweifach, New York industrial promoter who has been trying to take over the company, and members of the management will meet Tuesday in Scranton to consider "an outside offer" for all their stock.
LONDON, Aug. 9--The Archbishop of Canterbury today described Lord Altrincham, critic of the Queen and the court, as "a very silly man."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9--The leading Yugoslav party weekly Komunist, reported today that "an abyss" still divided the Soviet Communist party from Yugoslavia's.
Lee Calhoun, the 1956 Olympic 110-meter high hurdles champion, was disqualified as an amateur yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 9 (AP)-- Josh Culbreath of Norristown, Pa., bettered the official world record for the 440-yard hurdles at Bislet Stadium tonight when he was clocked in 50.5 seconds.
A law partner of the Republican state chairman has been picked as a Republican candididate for Town Councilman in Oyster Bay, L.I., on recommendation of Leonard W. Hall, the Republican town chairman.
SEATTLE, Aug. 9 (AP)--The speed boat Breathless of Piedmont, Calif., caught fire during a Gold Cup qualifying run today and the driver suffered burns before he was rescued.

KERSHA, Oman, Aug. 9-- Unexpected resistance by the forces of the Imam of Oman caused a mixed British and Muscat force to pause today for a general overhaul before attacking Farq, about two miles north of Kersha.

BAARLE-HERTOG, Belgium, Aug. 8--Approximately thirty acres, nine houses and a casino are at issue in a border dispute here between the Dutch and Belgian Governments. The issue will soon come before the International Court of Justice at the Hague.
Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was uneventful. Balancing of holdings for the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that crop prospects made some gains during July and now promised total production approaching the average of the last five years.

William J. Forster of 19 East Eightieth Street, a partner in Harris, Kerr, Ferster Co., accountants here, died Thursday of a heart attack at the Rangely Lakes, in Maine, where he was on vacation. His age was 73.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP)--Passenger car production in the nation this week included the year's four-millionth unit, nearly two weeks earlier than last year's comparable unit.
HONG KONG, Aug. 9--Communist China's cities are getting too big too fast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--A House subcommittee angrily charged the Administration with lack of cooperation today. It then suspended its hearings into the State Department's plan for returning German assets seized in this country during World War II.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 9--On one of the most encouraging days for American tennis in recent years, all three of Australia's high ranking representatives were beaten in the Eastern grass court championships today.
A huge expansion of the world's tanker fleet appears to be certain within the next fifteen years.

Reports that the city was scrutinizing the outside activities of twenty-two employes of the City Housing Authority were confirmed yesterday at the office of Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9-- On the eve of his eighty-third birthday anniversary, Herbert Hoover sighted two clouds over the country today. One was "the cloud of inflation," the other, the "possibility of war."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today the name of James H. Smith Jr. as director of the International Cooperation Administration.
Prices of cotton futures declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive day, closing 17 to 32 (85 cents to $1.60 a bale) points off on fairly heavy trading.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 9--Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester C.C. retained her Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9--The reported escapades of some leading Hollywood stars and other celebrities were cited by the defense today in the criminal libel conspiracy Trial of Confidential Magazine.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9-- Premier Adnan Menderes ended today a four-day, 650-mile tour of the Black Sea area of Turkey. During the trip he exhausted an entourage that gradually increased from fifty persons to three times that number.
Governor Harriman joined yesterday the fight against labor racketeers and employers who prey upon Puerto Rican and Negro workers.

BERLIN, Aug. 9--Nikita S. Khrushchev's program for adjusting Communist political action to new world conditions was outlined yesterday in the Soviet leader's speech to the Volkskammer, lower house of the East German Parliament.
AS sure a sign of August as corn and peaches is the crop of new furniture that blossoms in the model rooms of department stores.

A number of organizations that call themselves patriotic--and doubtless are--sent witnesses this week before tha Senate subcommittee to oppose any "weakening" of our immigration law. One such witness, Mrs. James C. Lucas, spoke for the American Coalition, which was said
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The House of Representatives passed tonight a bill to give an 11 per cent pay rise to nearly 4,000,000 Government employes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9--Back at the old cavalry post where he won the Flash Stakes two years ago, the Woodley Lane Farm's 4-year-old colt Reneged took first money in the best of the Saratoga races today. He won by a head at the end of a dead-game stretch run. He was the $8.50-for-$2 third choice.
LONDON, Aug. 9--The stock market finished the week in a quiet mood today mostly with small irregular movements. Once again store shares scored the biggest gains that ranged up to 3s 9d (52 cents).

There will be little occasion, we believe, to challenge President Eisenhower's nomination of Neil H. McElroy to be our next Secretary of Defense. The appointment is obviously a good one. A strong man has been found for an extremely difficult post.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9--The trading volume in wheat on the Board of Trade today was light. There was no demand for flour from bakers or jobbers, and export business remained light.

A contract to purchase the seven-story building containing sixty-seven furnished apartments at 465 Central Park West, near West 106th Street, has been resold by A. Loehrs. Irving Bira was the broker in the sale to an investor. The plot is 50 by 100 feet.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 9--India tartly rejected today charges by Pakistan that the New Delhi Government was systematically colonizing Kashmir in an attempt to head off a United Nations plebiscite there.
Plans for the fall presentation of two original plays off-Broadway were announced yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 9-- A funeral service for Hoyt Miller, a chemist and for many years a vice president and director of the New York Times Company, was held this afternoon at All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10-- The "Big Three" in California Republican politics have succeded in arousing voters from dog days lethargy.

CONNAUGHT RANGES, Ont., Aug. 10 (Canadian Press)--Gilmour Boa of Toronto, the 1956 Canadian small bore rifle champion, took the lead in the first two stages of a three-stage fight for the Sportsman's Challenge Trophy today.

CARMEL, CALIF. THE Bach Festival of Car mel, Calif., in its twentieth season this summer expanded both its range of program and the audience it reached. It was broadcast for the first time (by a noncommercial FM station).
KNOXVILLE, Aug. 10--Tennessee Valley Authority power system plants produced a record 61,400,000,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity in the 1957 fiscal...

Freedom of the press is the greatest enemy of tyranny. It is also the greatest friend of liberty. These truisms were realized long ago. The men who formed the United States knew so well that liberty is impossible without freedom of the press that the principle is enshrined in the very first amendment to our Constitution.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug 10 --Experience now shows that among the surest ways for an Asian country to become especially remarkable in the United States is for it to go Communist, be threatened by communism or have an ambassadordesignate not know the name of its Prime Minister.

SAINTE-BEUVE used to com plain that youthful writers in his era were given to trop de durete--which may be translated as "an excess of toughness." In our less sensitive age, armor-plated realism seems to be expected of the young novelist. Arthur Foff has written...
WITHIN the last two years a new organization has appeared on the modern dance scene. The group, which calls itself Contemporary Dance Productions, has given three ...

MOSCOW, Aug. 10--All children in the Latvian city of Riga from 6 to 14 years old are being inoculated this summer with Soviet-made antipolio vaccine patterned after that developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk in the United States.
BOULDER,, Colo., Aug. 10-- The atomic era is making national standards of time and radio frequency obsolete.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--If and when the political smoke clears and Congress enacts a civil rights bill along the lines of the present Senate version, the country will begin getting some practical answers to the much-argued question of how effective a measure it is.

ANYONE who has followed the recent career of Evelyn Waugh knows that he is now perhaps the best polemicist of our day. As his novelistic powers have suffered a decline and fall, his capacity to chop down his enemies has become, by compensation, truly impressive.
Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Aug. 3, were 1 per cent below those in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board has reported.
An Air Force rocket pilot and two Navy balloonists were named yesterday as winners of the 1957 Harmon International Aviation Awards for outstanding skill as pilots.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 10--The resident Time Magazine correspondent here, Robert W. Rosenhouse, was beaten last night at the doorstep of his suburban home.

THE trial of Marshal Ney was the cause celebre of the year 1815, the year of Napoleon's return from Elba and of the Battle of Waterloo. To that year, so rich in dramatic impact and in swift changes of...
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10-- The engagement of Miss Isabella Margaret Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Maxon Phillips, to Kenneth Windsor Inch...

FULGENCIO BATISTA y ZALDIVAR, Major General, President of Cuba, dictator, the individual who has run that largest of Caribbean Islands off and on for nearly a quarter of a century, is quite a man. What kind of man is partly a matter of opinion and preference, but anyone who can dominate a scene as violent,...
ATHENS, Aug. 10--The Balkan military pact signed three years ago appears to be a dead letter, at least with the Greek people. Its anniversary yesterday went unnoticed.

HONG KONG, Aug. 10--New industries, expanding trade and a spectacular building boom are effecting one of the Far East's outstanding economic success stories in this little appendage of mainland China.
One-way streets and other changes have been proposed to reduce traffic congestion and accidents in the downtown business district of Brooklyn.

THE Pentagon has begun to de-classify some ingenious navigation devices of singular interest to transAtlantic airlines. They are "Doppler radar" devices which are already in wide use on military planes. They hold considerable promise of breaking up the...
MANY plants may be rescued from the garden to serve as house plants during the winter. The sooner the operations get under way, the better established the plants will be for the months ahead.
WESTMINSTER has recently released the fourth disk in its projected recording of the complete Mozart symphonies by the London Philharmonic Symphony under Erich Leinsdorf.

GENEVA, Aug. 7--Eight countries participating in an experimental system of multilateral trade agreed on compensation transfers totaling $7,200,000 during the first month of the program, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.
The case history of how a "paper" union was driven from a plant and an employer forced to recognize a legitimate labor group was related yesterday by Alex Rose.

MODERN automabiles have been getting wider every year--with the result that many a homeowner is discovering that his new car has outgrown his old, narrow driveway. This problem is particularly acute at the point...
Budgetary procedures, a perennial problem of the Pentagon, are again troubling Congress and the Department of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The nearest thing to a firm estimate of political gain and loss yet possible in the great Congressional struggle over civil rights concerns the longterm power equation in Congress itself.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (UP)-- Al Smith's wild throw in the ninth inning opened the gates for three runs today and enabled the Kansas City Athletics to defeat the Cleveland Indians, 8--5.

Russian arms continue to pour into the Middle East. Syria is where the main build-up has been taking place this year and Egypt has been receiving replacements for the arms lost to Israel, plus some new features like the three submarines recently delivered.
ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP)--Governor Harriman today stayed the execution of Angelo LaMarca, the kidnap-slayer of the Weinberger baby, until a new plea could be brought before the Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13--The House of Representatives approved this evening, 256 to 129, an annual increase of more than $500,000,000 in postage charges.
State Republican and Democratic leaders claimed credit yesterday for Congress' approval of legislation to allow the development of hydroelectric power on the Niagara River.

BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 13-- The National Bureau of Standards is building a pilot plant here in plans to produce scarce "heavy water" inexpensively.
LONDON, Aug. 13--The stock market was unsettled today. South African gold mining shares advanced as British Government securities fell on the weakness of sterling. Industrials were dull.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13--Wheat futures set seasonal highs again today on all but the September, which equalled the old record for the crop. Wheat opened easy and then rallied into new high ground.

ELK RIDGE, Md., Aug. 13 (AP) --Francis X. Pavesich, the first director of the Loan Guaranty Division of the Veterans Administration and a former investment banker, died last night at his home of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.
The City Council opened the doors to a larger registration of voters-yesterday by approving forty-one new branches for central registration.
Following is a list of the city's Boards of Elections and their branch offices at which voters may register and enroll under the new system of permanent personal registration.
GARDEN CITY, L.I. Aug. 13 --Long Island golfers scored their third victory in a row in the annual triangular team competition against Westchester and New Jersey today.
A closed circuit, pay-as-yousee television system was demonstrated here yesterday by the International Telemeter Corporation, a subsidiary of the Paramount Pictures Corporation.

BOSTON, Aug. 13--Mickey Mantle, meeting his redoubtable rival, Ted Williams, man to man tonight before a gathering of 35,647, the largest of the year; at the Hub, gained a double triumph for himself.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 13--An industrial arbitration group today ordered an end to the twoday jurisdictional strike that has made 15,000 workers idle in Long Island's construction industry.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 13 (AP) --Five Russian engineers visited the University of Minnesota and its farm campus in St. Paul today. Their tour will end at the Minnesota State Fair on or about Labor Day.

Bruno Funaro, Associate Professor of Architecture and assistant dean in charge of evening classes of the Columbia University School of Architecture, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. His age was 46. He resided at 257 West Eighty-sixth Street.
An interesting problem in diplomacy is presented by the controversy over the proposed visit of forty-odd young Americans to Communist China.
Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading as featureless in most markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- Senator John L. McClellan said today that Johnny Dio "obviously had some kind of supervisory position" over New York locals of a labor union months after he ostensibly had resigned his post in the organization.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13-- Making his first appearance in the tournament, Hamilton Richardson narrowly averted the loss of the opening set in defeating James Farrin of Princeton today in the Newport invitation tennis fixture at the Casino.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 13-- Charles H. Duryea, former chairman of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors and a leader in the Republican party in this area, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 70.
LONDON, Aug. 13--The West pressed the Soviet Union unsuccessfully today for a reaction to proposals for disarmament inspection zones in North America, Europe and the Soviet Union.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13--This was another afternoon at the Saratoga track when the 2-year-olds attracted much of the attention.

DETROIT, Aug. 13--Mendel Lurie, a New York attorney who solicited proxies in opposition to the management, has been elected to the five-man board of directors of the Superior Tool and Die Company, it was announced today.
Three garbage collectors and a pantryman were arrested last night on charges of stealing frozen shrimp and olive oil from Leone's Restaurant at 239 West Forty-eighth Street.

LODZ, Poland, Wednesday, Aug. 14--Polish Army and police units today occupied three street-car terminals taken over Monday by drivers and conductors on shrike for more pay. About 3,000 policemen and troops advanced on the main terminal. No resistance was offered by the strikers. The incident lasted about fifteen minutes.
Mayor Wagner denied yesterday a charge that his administration was stalling until after Election Day any action on the controversial bill to bar discrimination in private apartment renting.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 13 (U.P.)--Mervyn Rose, a seasoned southpaw from Australia, needed only fifty minutes today to beat Pierro Darmon of France, 6--3, 6--0, 6--1, in the men's singles final of the German international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) --Brig. Gen. Urban Niblo, who held high Army Ordnance assignments before his retirement two years ago, died here today at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 59 years old.

POINT JUDITH, R.I. Aug. 13--Hardly enough tuna salad was caught here today in the first round of the United States Atlantic tuna tournament to keep church socials going for a week in a small town. But one good fish did prevent skunkage.

Just how big is inflation's bite on the American economy?. In 1956, according to the Institute of Life Insurance, it was $83,000,000,000. That was the largest in any year since 1947, although the price trend has been almost steadily upward for a decade.

MOSCOW, Aug.13--The United States Government warned a group of American youths here today against making their scheduled trip to Communist China. The trip would be in defiance of State Department regulations.

PARIS, Aug. 13--France has long been known for douceur de vivre. Adoring foreigners enjoy the delicious contrast between sophisticated Paris and a tranquil, unchanging countryside almost as lovely as in a medieval Book of Hours.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP)-- Lew Burdette, a right-hander, slammed his first two home runs as a major league player tonight --good for four runs--and doled out eight hits as the Milwaukee Braves trounced the Cincinnati Redlegs, 12--4.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 13-- Syria ordered the ouster of three United States Embassy officials tonight after accusing the United States of having plotted to overthrow President Shukri al-Kuwatly's regime. The three must leave the country tomorrow.

Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel of the Soviet secret police appeared in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday morning still without counsel. Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo gave the spy case defendant until Friday morning to engage a lawyer and promised to appoint counsel if the quest were unsuccessful.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 13 --George Miller of 90 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, proprietor of Miller's Restaurants at 233 Broadway and 144 Fulton Street, New York, died here today in his summer home. He would have been 89 years old on Aug. 25.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 12-- Having failed to locate a gap in Turkey's armor by means of a diplomatic offensive, the Soviet Union is trying to soften the Turks' anti-Communist attitude by offering industrial aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- Senate members of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy questioned John S. Graham and John F. Floberg for an hour today and then unanimously recommended their confirmation as members of the Atomic Energy Commission.
The world's championship rodeo in Pendleton, Ore., will be televised Sept. 14 from 8 to 9 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
We have known for some time that the days of Carnegie Hall were numbered. We have followed the plans to transfer the home of the Philharmonic Orchestra to a new and perhaps better location.
ATHENS, Ga., Aug. 13 (AP)-- Dr. William Lorenzo Moss, known for his research in the fields of blood groupings and of tropical and hemorrhagic diseases, died yesterday. His age was 86.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) --Two teetotaling Senators urged that drinking on airlines be outlawed.
THE dentist from Northwestern University who has scored a triumph in the elections in British Guiana is a man no official in Britain's Government would call painless.

Currency devaluation, largely unknown before World War I, has become a commonplace instrument of national policy in both capitalist and Communist nations. The latest was the virtual devaluation of the French franc last weekend.

Every new contagious disease that looms over the city's horizon is a test of the Health Department's professional skill and practical judgment. It has drastic powers corresponding to its heavy responsibilities to protect the city's health.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13-- Leslie Combs 2d is a cheerful guy with a constant smile. He has a right to be cheerful. He heads the syndicate that owns Nashua, the million-dollar horse. Like all horse breeders, the breezy Combs lives in the future, constantly gazing ahead.
Mayor Wagner's bill to exempt the first 90 cents of motion picture admission charges from the city's 5 per cent amusement tax was passed by the City Council yesterday.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Some trade sources said the recent qualified devaluation of the French franc and rumors that English sterling might be devalued may have caused the lower prices here. Trading was dull.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Aug. 20 --The marriage of Miss Katharine McPherson Page to Norman Larribee Alling took place here this afternoon in the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rugg. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Lattimore Alling of Rochester.

The screams of a woman bank teller who tripped an alarm, then fainted, thwarted a hold-up yesterday a block west of Times Square. Shaken by the turn of events, the thug fled and disappeared into the midday throng.

The strike of milk truck drivers that had threatened the metropolitan area with severe shortages ended suddenly early yesterday morning. It had lasted thirty-four hours and had had no effect on supplies to 12,000,000 consumers.

Girard told the Maebashi District Court this morning he had no intention of hitting anyone when he fired his rifle on a maneuver ground. last Jan. 30. The shell casing he fired killed Mme. Naka Sakai, who was collecting expended shell cases to sell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --The Bureau of Census reported today that cotton consumption for the July period averaged 25,494 bales for each working day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--The way was opened today for adoption by the House of Representatives tomorrow of the Senate's Democratic version of the Administration's civil rights bill. BOSTON, Aug. 26--An initial step was taken today toward formation of a joint council of the arts in education.

Marian Anderson's concert tour in Far Eastern countries will be filmed by the Columbia Broadcasting System for presentation on Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" television program.

The Copperweld Steel Company and the Superior Steel Corporation, with combined assets approximating $71,500,000, yesterday agreed in principle on a plan of merger. Copperweld Steel, however, was off three-eighths of a point with the final quotation at 32 5/8.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, Aug. 26--Seven hundred thousand Poles assembled here tonight to demonstrate their loyalty to their Roman Catholic faith and their Primate, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski.

SEASON dates for the hunting of migratory water fowl in upstate New York and Long Island were set yesterday by Conservation Commissioner Sharon J. Mauhs.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Aug. 26--Howland Spencer, a former neighbor of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today at his home on Harbour Island. Mr. Spencer, who sold his property near Mr. Roosevelt's Hyde Park, N.Y., estate to Father Divine, established his home on Harbour Island nearly twenty years ago. He was 67 years old.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26--All grain futures declined today, but soybeans rose.

Wool prices fell yesterday in one of the sharpest declines of the year on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops fell 3.3 to 5.5 cents a pound and grease wool dropped 4.3 to 6 cents. The near-by months were weakest. Volume was heavy.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 26--In the second week of the festival here the only new dramatic offering is "Man of Distinction," a brash and metallic comedy of pre-Hitler Germany by Walter Hasenclever.

William J. O'Donnell made his 181st "arrest" and saw his 181st prisoner convicted yesterday in Felony Court. This is unusual not only because of the conviction record but also because Mr. O'Donnell is a subway conductor.

An application from the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen for affiliation with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, supported by a 4-to-1 referendum vote of its members, was submitted recently to the federation's executive council.
PARIS, Aug. 26--A general price freeze is expected to be announced for France tomorrow or Wednesday.

DOVER PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 26--Alfred Geiffert Jr., head of the landscape architectural firm that bears his name at 101 Park Avenue, New York, died today at his farm here. His age was 66. He livid at 27 West Tenth Street, New York.

Army Specialist Girard, charged with the manslaughter of a Japanese woman on an American rifle range, has been put on trial before a provincial Japanese court of three judges who now have a grave international responsibility to follow the law rather than bow to the public clamor around them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--A bill to regulate disclosure of the reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in criminal cases passed the Senate by voice vote tonight. Earlier Administration efforts to toughen the measure were rejected.
Fifty-eight more suspected cases of Asian flu were reported here yesterday. If confirmed by laboratory tests, they will bring to ninety-eight the number of cases to reach the city so far.

The stock market took another beating yesterday. Prices were marked down fractions to 3 points, and the average approached the lows of the year, reached back in February.

PORTLAND, Conn., Aug. 26 --Ansel A. Packard, assistant to the president of the Connecticut Power Company and long active as a Mason, died at his home here today. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --Personal income in the United States last year reached a record of $324,000,000,000. This was an average of $1,940 for every man, woman and child in the country--before taxes, that is.
PARIS, Aug. 26--Givenchy today and Balenciaga tomor row are at last showing the fall fashion collections to the stray bits of press still left in Paris.

A Presidential fact-finding board continued hearings here yesterday in an attempt to settle a wage dispute involving captains and deckhands on ferries and tugboats of eleven railroads serving New York.
Mayor Wagner ordered yesterday that vigorous police action be taken against "hardcore problem children."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26-- American investment abroad and earnings from past investments both reached record levels last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP)--This is the eighty-fourth birthday of Dr. Lee De Forest, the inventor who made radio broadcasting possible. His comment: "Now I'm shooting for 94."

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 26-- Arthur F. McConville's Bobby King, a 9-year-old black gelding from Ogdensburg, N.Y., scored a head victory over Senator Byrd in 2:03 3/5 in the Shenandoah pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26-- Brazil has interrupted all imports for about thirty days to allow trade and foreign currency readjustments under her new tariff law.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP)--A Navy flier was killed today in the flaming crash of his small training plane in the village of Clinton. At least seventeen persons, including thirteen children, in the vicinity escaped unscathed.
Three directors of the PennTexas Corporation yesterday called for the resignation of Leopold D. Silberstein as chairman and president and asked for a special board meeting to be held on Thursday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer wraps himself in the United States flag in the course of asking the voters to return him to power a third time.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 26 --Foreign Minister Salah elBitar said today the United States policy of demanding alignment against the East had made it difficult for Syria to seek aid from or have any dealings with the Western powers.

A recent news story from City Hall about a Board of Estimate meeting carried this paragraph: "The board voted, subject to approval by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame, to spend $33,400 for a thorough inspection of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument at Riverside Drive and Eighty-ninth Street."
BONN, Germany, Aug. 28-- Moscow's proposal that SovietWest German trade be built up to a $500,000,000-a-year business in the next four years is under cool consideration here.
The District Attorney's office in Queens yesterday asked for another month in which to investigate an alleged "mistaken identity" case.
LONDON, Aug. 28--The Soviet Union pressed the West today to remove the conditions attached to its proposal for a two-year suspension of nuclear weapons tests.
Directors of the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday elected a new chairman and president. The changes are effective Nov. 1.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Ted Williams broke up a tense pitching duel between Boston's Frank Sullivan and Detroit's Jim Bunning today, belting a seventh-inning home run that enabled the Red Sox to post a 1-0 triumph over the Tigers.

BOB SCHEFFING was frowning as he walked out to the mound for a talk with Dick Drott, his precocious 21 year-old pitcher. The Cub manager had seen too many games go gallumping down the drain this season and he Was taking no chances. Drott had had the St. Louis Cardinals on the way to a 3-0 shutout, but it looked as if the youngster was losing his grip.
NEWARK, Aug. 28--A scientific test of the Drunkometer proved today what many might have guessed--that if you drink whisky all day you get drunk.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Most wheat contracts and all other grain futures declined on the Board of Trade today, as a last-minute wave of selling and hedging erased early gains.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Soviet legal scholars are considering the most far-reaching, suggestions yet made here in the current drive to liberalize the Soviet Union's criminal code.
Domestic crude oil production in the week ended last Friday averaged 6,788,500 barrels a day, a new low for the year, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
A report by a Communist Yugoslav professor of economics recommending solutions to basic world economic problems in terms of traditional capitalistic principles was acclaimed here yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 27 --Turkey's three Opposition parties are considering boycotting the next elections if the Government blocks their effort to present a united front against the dominant Democratic party.

Fare reductions ranging from 7 to 25 per cent on sailings from this country and Canada to Europe will be placed in effect Sunday by the twenty-eight member lines of the Trans-At lantic Passenger Conference.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked by an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage unless specified.

Plans for modernizing 221 West Thirty-eighth Street, in the heart of the garment district were announced yesterday by Joseph B. Rosenblatt and Rennold Wacht, investor's, who recently bought the building.

A $42,600,000 treble damage anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Deep South Oil Company of Texas against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, two gas corporations and five individuals. It charged a conspiracy in the production and sale of natural gas.

Off the shore of Louisiana one of the World's biggest oil drilling rigs is operating in water seventy-seven feet deep. Dubbed Mr. Gus 2d, the massive unit weighs as much as five destroyers and generates enough power to supply a city of 30,000.

The economic woes of the Chinese Red regime are again becoming apparent. A new rationing edict on cotton cloth has been announced. A further 20 per cent cut is decreed and women are urged to change their style of dress to use less raw material. The army is already put on short clothing ration and this is the second civilian cut this year.
CRIMINAL MAN, by George Godwin (George Braziller, $4). A study in criminology.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) --Conrad Jobst, an engineer who invented a custom-fitted elastic stocking to ease his varicose veins, and turned the device into a thriving business, died Monday. His age was 67.
Chicago, Ill., received bids yesterday on $15,000,000 of school bonds. The best purchase offer was a price representing an interest cost of 3.642 per cent.

Law enforcement officials will debate the cause and cure of juvenile delinquency on a special television program titled "The Big Issue." It will be presented on Tuesday, Sept. 10, from 7:30 to 8 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
Dr. Alfred L. Shapiro testified yesterday that he had been ordered to continue his duties as an assistant medical examiner despite the fact that he was suffering from a serious liver ailment.

HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Mrs. Robert E. Pegel's Chicago Yacht Club crew used a 15-mile wind effectively to gain a tie in the fourth race and then placed second in the fifth today to hold its lead in the four-day thirtieth annual North American women's sailing championship.
HONG KONG, Aug. 28 -- Small clandestine factories are the latest manifestation of efforts to circumvent communization in Shanghai, former citadel of free enterprise in China.
Estimates vary on how long an influenza vaccine will protect against the disease.

A new issue of $60,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company will be placed on the market today at ha price to yield 4.81 per cent to investors holding the bonds to maturity in 1987.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 28-The new Grace Liner Santa Rosa slipped into the James River here today to open a new phase in the history of American shipbuilding.
The country's gas appliance manufacturers expect factory unit sales of their products this year to fall substantially below the 1956 level but anticipate a partial recovery in 1958.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28--With proud references to its newly tested intercontinental ballistic missile, the Soviet Union warned the Western nations today on their stand at the London disarmament talks. It told them they had better meet the Soviet position "halfway."

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Tyson Goodridge of Princeton and Jackson, Wyo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Tyson Goodridge, to Ensign John Hardy Thomas, U.S.N.

Two more concerns have taken office space in the thirtyeight-story Seagram Building, which is rising at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street. The leases were announced by L'Huillier S. Sheaff, president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- President Eisenhower signed seventy-four bills today. It was tie largest number in any one day of the current Congressional session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 --A feature motion picture which will have artificial insemination as the central theme will be co-produced this fall by Raymond Stross and Cine-World Productions, a New York film company. The picture, "A Question of Adultery," will be made in England.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) Wally Post's seventeenth homer capped a six-run Redleg barrage in the second inning and Cincinnati then halted a Philadelphia uprising in the eighth for a 6-5 victory over the Phillies tonight.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 28 (AP)-Attorneys for a group of Loew's, Inc., stockholders asked the Delaware Court of Chancery today to prohibit or postpone a meeting of stockholders called by Joseph R. Vogel, president of Loew's.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The House of Representatives passed today a Senate-approved bill to correct hardships arising under the present immigration laws. The vote was 293 to 58.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Arnold R. Jones indicated today that he would not accept a recess appointment as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority if the Senate did not act on his nomination before adjournment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Informal efforts were begun today to adjust House-Senate differences on a bill to restrict the disclosure of Government files in criminal trials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --Farm assets rose to a record $176,800,000,000 last Jan. 1, but farm debt also reached a new high, the Federal Reserve System said today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP)--Ronnie Kline of the Pittsburgh Pirates hurled a six-hit shutout tonight as the cellar-dwelling Bucs beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0. The defeat kept the Cards seven and one-half games back of first-place Milwaukee.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 28-- A Federal grand jury, for the second time, accused Dave Beck of income-tax evasion today. It also charged that his son and four others had conspired with him to conceal his true income as president of the International Brother...

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28-A stunned Wisconsin Republican party sought an explanation today of its overwhelming defeat yesterday in the election of a Senator to complete the unexpired term of the late Joseph R. McCarthy.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP) --Craig Rice, mystery writer, was found dead in her apartment tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Secretary of the Treasury told key members of Congress today that the Government was "ready to try to operate" for this fiscal year within the $275,000,000,000 ceiling on the national debt.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) --The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet has abolished the Ministry of State Control, Tass, Soviet news agency, announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 (UP)--Pink Velvet, the 3-2 favorite, made the most of a strong ride by Walter Blum to defeat Salix by a half-length in the $23,400 Margate Handicap for fillies and mares today before a crowd of 20,962.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --President Eisenhower signed today a bill giving the Interstate Commerce Commission stronger controls over permits to engage in domestic freight forwarding.

The Eastern Tennis Patrons Association junior development program will receive the proceeds from the first International Tennis Ball. The event will be held in the gardens of the West Side Tennis Club,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --Senator Gordon Allott, Republican of Colorado, introduced a bill today to revive the expining program of buying tungsten for the defense stockpile.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Aug. 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Archer have made known the engagement of Mrs. Archer's daughter, Miss Beulah Victoria Harold, to Prof. Hugh Morris Gloster. He is the son of the late Prof. and Mrs. John R. Gloster of Memphis, Tenn.
A 5-year-old girl who was feared to have been kidnaped reappeared in East Harlem yesterday morning. She had spent the night with a motherly neighbor.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 28--Research into the infinitely small parts of the living cell is being conducted at a level so delicate that cosmic rays are interfering with it.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP)-- The final obstacle to construction of a plant here by the Carting Brewery Company has been removed.
The first endowed chair of physical medicine and rehabilitation in a medical school has been set up at the New York University College of Medicine. Dean Donal Sheehan announced Yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 28--Football and intercontinental missiles became parts of the West German election campaign today.
Leopold D. Silberstein, president and chairman of PennTexas Corporation, entered Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday suffering from an internal ailment.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad experienced a loss of $689,120 in July. In the 1956 month the road cleared $93,435. Operating revenues, however, were slightly higher, $12,829,911 against $12,556,258.

GIRARD, Pa., Aug. 28--The Most Rev. Aloysius Grosse Kappenberg, Superior General of the Roman Catholic Society of the Divine Word, died yesterday of leukemia at the clinic of the Missionary Sisters of the Holy Ghost in Rome. His age was 67.

The terror that has ruled in the Communist party here and in Communist-ruled Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is described from an insider's point of view by the novelist Howard Fast in an article to be published shortly.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 28--A campaign to intimidate the Negroes who enrolled their children in white schools began here today.

Atlas Corporation had record net assets of $125,472,743, equal to $9.72 a share, on June 30, according to a report released yesterday. This compared with $104,815,285, or $9.50 a share, a year earlier. The increase in the net asset value was about 8.6 per cent, before deducting divi
The rally in the bond market seemed to run out of breath yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28--Charles Comiskey, the vice president of the White Sox, tonight revealed that the Chicagoans had made offers to buy Sal Maglie of the Brooklyn Dodgers and Virgil Trucks of the Kansas City Athletics. Maglie is 40 and Trucks is 38.
Commodity futures generally rose yesterday on the New York exchanges. However, trading in most markets was uneventful.
DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 28 (AP) --The Hambletonian Society's board of directors today extended the present contract to hold the harness racing fixture at the Du Quoin State Fair Grounds for one year.

CHICAGO, Thursday, Aug. 29--Early this morning Casey Stengel and his Yankees breathed a great sigh of relief. They had just emerged from a gruelling struggle in which, to the bitter disappointment of a crowd of 36,917, they had downed Al Lopez' spunky White Sox, 5 to 4.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28--The United States is campaigning to obtain the post of director general of the new International Atomic Energy Agency for Representative W. Sterling Cole.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 28--The British, getting ready to haul down the Union Jack in another part of their disappearing Asian empire, got a special sort of farewell present today from the leader of a country they will no longer rule.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28-- Another Argentine cabinet crisis appeared in the making tonight as Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu called the chiefs of the armed services and civilian economic advisers to a special conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican leader of the Senate, balked at letting Wisconsin's new Democratic Senator take his seat tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 (UP)--The United States, in a concession to Latin America, agreed today to consider the advisability of setting up a special international bank or fund to finance development projects in under-developed areas.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 28 --A half-century-old archaeological puzzle about the language used in an ancient system of Cretan writing has been ended. The solution by Prof. Cyrus H. Gordon of Brandeis University here gives Akkadian, the Babylonian language, as the long-sought answer.

Making the first and third outs in the inning, Willie Mays had nothing at all to do with the eight rung the Giants scored in the third frame against the flag-bound Milwaukee Braves yesterday at the Polo Grounds. To put it bluntly, the only contributions by the Say Hey Kid to the 12-6 rout of the visitors were on defense.

Central registration ended for the year last night. The final results will not be known until today but indications were that upward of 560,000 persons here had taken advantage of this opportunity to qualify as voters.
PARIS, Aug. 28--France's new limited price freeze drew from business and labor spokesmen today expressions of hostility, skepticism and faint hopes, but no sign of enthusiasm.

A SURE sign of fall: The announcement of a new course for home cooks in international cuisine that will be given at the Lexington Hotel on five successive Tuesdays from 10:30 A.M. to approximately 1:30 P.M., starting Sept. 10.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 28 -The Ford Motor Company conceded today that its 1958 cars would cost more than the current models.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Children fare better after divorces if they have had some advance feeling that their parents' separation was in the making, sociologists were told today.

President Eisenhower's comment yesterday on the Zorin statement delivered at the London disarmament conference, but of course written in Moscow, illustrates the difference between honest discussion and the familiar Soviet variety of dishonest and venomous propaganda.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 28-- The annual Canadian National Exhibition, which during its two-week run now under way will play host to about 3,000,000 visitors, plans a sharp expansion of its international exhibits in an effort to fill the gap left by the shutdown of the Canadian International Trade Fair two years ago.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has gathered from an expert group new ideas on persuading teen-agers to take Salk vaccine shots against polio.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 (AP)--An official announcement tonight said ninety-four persons were missing in the sinking of an Argentine river craft following a collision with a United States freighter last night.
LONDON, Aug. 28--The demand for high-class industrial stocks broadened today under the influence of a firm British Government securities section and yesterday's Wall Street rise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -The Government eased today export control on goods destined for Poland. It gave the Communist nation a trade status nearly equal to any of its closest allies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The surgeon General of the Public Health Service announced the release of 562,610 doses of Asian flu vaccine today. He also said much more than expected might be available by Jan. 1.
