PARIS, Sept. 1 (Reuters)-- King Mohammed V of Morocco will doubtless discuss the issue of United States bases in Morocco on his official visit this fall to the United States, Crown Prince Moulay Hassan said here tonight.

Seven Broadway shows will cater to the holiday trade by giving special matinees today. They are "A Visit to a Small Planet," "Bells Are Ringing." "Damn Yankees," "Happy Hunting," "Li'l Abner." "No Time for Sergeants" and "The Most Happy Fella."
Work on the Republic of China's largest electric power project on Formosa (Taiwan) is now two-thirds completed, spokesmen for the Taiwan Power Company reported here over the week-end.

With the tying run on first base and two out in the ninth, Roy Campanella yesterday ducked away from a two-two pitch from Mary Grissom. It was a good curve for a third strike, despite Campy's loud protests to the plate umpire, Dusty Boggess.

YANKTON, S.D., Sept. 1-- Hans Berliner of Washington, Curt Brasket of Tracy, Minn., and Gilbert Ramirez of San Francisco were deadlocked for the lead today with scores of 2 -- after three rounds of the Champion of Champions chess tournament.

J.R. Strother has been appointed general managaer of the eastern region of the Canadian Pacific Railway. Mr. Strother succeeds J.N. Fraine, recently named vice president of the Pacific region. Mr. Strother joined the company in 1912 in the telegraph department in Montreal. Last March he was appointed assistant general manager of the eastern region.

BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 1-- Harold Halsted's Chuckle, a Star Class boat of the Bellport Bay Fleet, captured the annual Queen of the Bay race today. She completed the 7.5-mile course in 2 hours 25 minutes 40 seconds to win on elapsed and corrected time.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1--Soviet school bells will summon more than 30,000,000 uniformed children to their desks tomorrow.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 1 --The Minister of National Economy called today for "limitation of economic freedom" to bring Syria into line with "advanced European countries."

DUBLIN, Sept. 1 (AP)--Kilkenny beat Waterford in the all-Ireland senior hurling final at Croke Park today. The score was Kilkenny: four goals and ten points (22 points); Waterford: three goals and twelve points (21 points).
President Eisenhower led the nation yesterday in tributes to its working men and women.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (UP) --The Phillies and Pirates split a double-header today. Pittsburgh routed Curt Simmons in the sixth to win the nightcap, 6--3, after the Phillies pounded four pitchers to give Robin Roberts an 11-3 victory in the opener.
Frank Lloyd Weight, whose views on architecture and other matters often have stirred controversy, was an imperturbable guest last night on the "Mike Wallace Interview" over Channel 7.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (UP)--An enthusiastic audience attended a triple premiere at the Festival Hall here last night. The event marked the first visits of Dimitri Mitropoulos and of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, and the ...
Shipping men apparently are backing the tobacco men in the controversy with the medicine men.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 --De Coursey Fales' staysail schooner Nina crossed the finish line first as the vanguard of a record fleet completed the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race tonight.

Erwin, Wasey Co, and Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., announced yesterday they had completed a merger. The new advertising agency, now known as Erwin Wasey, Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., has elected David B. Williams as president.
The owners of 1950 automobiles were reminded yesterday that their vehicles must pass safety inspection this month if they are to be operated legally.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1--J.R.D. Tata, chairman of the Tata Iron and Steel Company, will go to the United States to try to raise a $35 million loan.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) --A Congressional leader in the atomic energy field said today President Eisenhower should tell the American people the full story of the need for nuclear testing and the dangers of fall-out.

KANSAS CITY, Sept, 1 (AP)-- Bill Fischer scattered six singles and batted in two runs today as the Chicago White Sox beat the Kansas City Athletics, 5--0. It was the fifteenth time the Atheltics had been shut out this year--most times in either league.

The Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Fullerton to Raymond Jackson Wilson. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jacob Trapp. There was a reception in the Gold Room of the Ambassador.
LONGMIRE, Wash., Sept. 1 (AP)--A Pennsylvania youth died today in a fall in a crevasse near the top of 14,410-foot Mount Ranier.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1--Raymond S. Pruitt, a retired Chicago corporation lawyer who figured prominently in the growth of the aviation industry, died today at Trail's End, his summer home in St. Joseph, Mich. He was 70 years old.
PARIS, Sept. 1 (AP)--Roger Riviere of France today broke the world's cycling record for five kilometers (3 1/8 miles) over a closed track. His time at the Parc des Princes was 6:08.2.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UP)-- Johnny Parsons of Van Nuys, Calif., today won the 100-mile national championship midget auto race at the Michigan State Fair, averaging 87.22 miles per hour. Parsons' time was 1 hour 9 minutes .07 seconds.
Gospel songs and an evangelist's plea to "seek Christ" rang out last night in midtown New York as the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham preached the farewell sermon of his crusade.
BONN, Aug. 30--Friedrich Krupp, heavy engineering company of Essen, Germany, announced today its total sales rose to 1,890,000,000 marks ($450,000,000) in the 1955-56 business year.

The two-story office building and off-street parking area at 27-16 Forty-first Avenue, in the Bridge Plaza section of Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Marshall Construction Company for occupancy.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept.1 (Reuters)--Defense Minister Duncan Sandys of Britain felt it was not right to depend entirely on another country for nuclear defense.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1--Two Minneapolis researchers suggest that there may be a relationship between leukemia and mongolism.

The marriage of Miss Nina Schick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schick of Forest Hills, Queens, to Alfred Appel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Appel of Great Neck, L.I., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Sky Terrace Room of the St. Moritz.
Charter rates for ocean-going bulk freight ships sank to new lows last week, shipping brokers reported at the week-end.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UP)-- Wally Moon's tenth-inning single scored Don Blasingame with the winning run today as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Chicago Cubs, 3--2.
LONDON, Sept. 1--Stock market dealers here ended a quiet week Friday.
Sal Maglie, the 40-year-old Barber who helped pitch the Giants to a couple of pennants and last year tossed the Dodgers into another, yesterday became the property of the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-- Senator William F. Knowland, always a strong backer of the Chinese Nationalist regime on Taiwan (Formosa), said today that he would not mind admitting Red Chinese newsmen to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) --Wisconsin's new Democratic, Senator, William Proxmire, said today that his election indicated national discontent with the Eisenhower Administration's farm and foreign policies.

According to a leading money man and churchman of Britain, the new national savings bond --the one that pays monthly lottery prizes--is doing the job laid out for it and is sure to play a major role in the future.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 --The Government's economic and fiscal policies came in for sharp criticism today from members of the ruling Congress party.
The American Cancer Society announced yesterday the award of 278 research grants totaling $5,970,566.

IT will be news to Maggie-- who has social ambitions and denies her comic strip husband, Jiggs, corned beef and cabbage because she considers it inelegant--that the pungent vegetable originated in ancient Greece, the cradle of culture.
It never happened, of course. It could not have happened, for nothing, simply nothing, could have ...
The Hertz Corporation has concluded negotiations to acquire the Hawaiian Car Rental Company of Honolulu from Earl Tracker, Hertz system licensee. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

THOMPSON, Conn., Sept. 1 --Bob Holbert of Warrington, Pa.; Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N.J., and Paul O'Shea of Rye, N.Y., were the principal winners in the Sports Car Club of America national championship races on the new twomile raceway here today.

Coal dealers and coal users would do well to heed the warning of Dr. Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, that they face summonses for the illegal sale or use of coal. Dealers and users have been reminded appropriately that the department's regulations ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 1 --Nashville school officials want to know what has become of fifty-eight Negro firstgraders who are eligible to attend previously all-white schools here but who have not registered.
Miss Juliet Weisman and Herbert M. Wachtell were married yesterday afternoon at the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. Siegfried Philip of the West End Synagogue.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 1--August E. Rankis of the Baltic Chess Club of New York clinched the championship of the New York State Chess Association today by winning his game in the eighth round of the annual tournament.

WARSAW, Sept. 1--Official announcement was made today of the long-projected visit of a Polish Communist party and Government delegation to Yugoslavia. No date was given but it was believed the talks with President Tito would take place about the middle of this month.
Barry Wilson, actor, has received a Fulbright Scholarship to study drama at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. His subject will be the English classics from Shakespeare to Shaw.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 1--Nearly 1,000 delegates representing 8,300,000 union members have assembled here for the opening tomorrow of the eighty-ninth annual conference of the Trades Union Congress.

Paul Masson Vineyards, producer of wines, champagnes, brandy and vermouths, had a sales increase of 24.2 per cent for the fiscal year ended July 31, according to Otto E. Meyer, executive vice president.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1 AP)--A Cinta (Chilean) airline flight starting Santiago to New York service at tourist fares is scheduled to reach Miami, Fla., tomorrow.

BEIRUT, Labanon, Sept. 1-- The curtain around the visit of Loy W. Henderson has given rise to fears here that the United States is seeking military action to bar the rise of Soviet influence in Syria.

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Aug. 27--Hitler's Eagle Nest broods above the town. Down in this Alpine valley community, the American eagle on a flagpole welcomes guests to the United States Army Recreation Area.

VIENNA, Sept. 1 (AP)--More than 8,000 refugees from Yugoslavia have illegally entered Austria in the past three months and asked asylum, creating a serious problem, the Austrian Government said today.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP)--Marine Staff Sgt. Emmet D. Duncan of El Cerrito, Calif., took the lead today in the service rifle division of the nattional high-power rifle championships with 297 of a possible 300 points.
HONG KONG, Sept. 1--The first Yugoslav Government representative to visit Communist North Vietnam, Vice President Svetozear Vukmanovic-Tempo, arrived today in Hanoi, the Hanoi radio reported.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 1 (AP) --Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to Washington, welcomed today what he called a renewed strengthening of ties in Israel's relations with the United States.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 1--Mike Monney's Boojum, a Raven Class boat, was the winner on handicap in the thirty-third annual Stratford Shoal overnight race sponsored by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, which ended today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1 --Cystinosis, a rare disease formerly considered fatal, has been discovered in a healthy 23year-old student at Harvard University.
A call for a "clean house" campaign within the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was issued yesterday by six of its local unions.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 1-- Latin-American delegates to the Inter-American Economic Conference saw little hope today for the approval of a binding general economic agreement.
Further evidence of a trend among the major airlines to cater to distaff trade is provided by Northeast Airlines. It announced yesterday that it would send a woman speaker ...
"NEVER underestimate the power of a woman"--or of a slogan.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1--Anthony F. Saidy of Douglaston, Queens, scored two victories today to take the lead in the New Jersey State Chess Federation championship with a score of 4--0.
TRENTON, Sept. 1--Gov. Robert B. Meyner will deliver a major address every week during his campaign for reelection in November, it was announced here today.
DUISBURG, Germany, Sept. 1 (AP)--Germany won three titles in the European rowing championships today to take two trophies from Russia.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 1--Quiet has returned to the money and stock markets, following recent upheavals caused by the virtual devaluation of the French franc.
Population in the metropolitan region--an area roughly within a fifty-mile radius of New York City--is outracing recreational facilities.

CAIRO, Sept. 1 (AP)--The Oman rebels said today they had repulsed two attacks by the Sultan's forces and also had captured some British weapons from the Sultan's men. Mohammed el Harthy, the rebels' representative in Cairo, said the attacks were on the Omani-held towns of Ghemr and Firq.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-- Congress has gone home. Capitol Hill reporters--those not catching up on sleep--are capping tales of the last exciting week, recalling little episodes that got crowded out in the press of the news.
Cotton futures prices moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange last week.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1 (UP)--Bob Crowley of Weston, Mass., clipped four strokes off par with brilliant putting today to retain the lead by two strokes in the Insurance City open golf tournament.

"Our Manpower Future" will be the subject of a conference planned by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York at the Commodore Hotel on Sept. 17. Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell and Dr. Eli Ginzberg of the National Manpower Council will speak.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP)--Anne Jill Michaelson, 8 years old, of 4 Dartmouth Street, Forest Hills, Queens drowned today while swimming in a private pool, near here. The girl, visiting here with her parents, went swimming alone in a pool at the home of Graham Gardner.
Miss Lois Joy Seekamp was married yesterday afternoon to George Frederick Dole in the New Church, Swedenborgian.
PRADES, France, Sept. 1 (UP) --Pablo Casals was reported to be recovering today from a sudden illness in this Pyrenees village near the Spanish border.
HONG KONG, Sept. 1--The campaign against "Rightists" in Communist China is continuing relentlessly and with increasing harshness.

NICE, France, Sept. 1 (AP)-- Sir Winston Churchill and Lady Churchill arrived today by plane from London for a holiday on the Riviera. The former British Prime Minister told newsmen his health was excellent and that he was feeling better than he had for five years. He and his wife plan to stay a month as guests of Lord Beaverbrook.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1-- Fifty-one contenders for the title of Miss America will arrive tomorrow to open the thirty-sixth Miss America Pageant here.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1-- Music popular in the United States sells as fast in Germany as it can be imported--and translated. West Germany's record industry sold no fewer than 2,000,000 copies of one title, "Heimweh" or homesickness, the German version of "Memories."

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 1-- Three prominent persons have accepted the posts of honorary chairmen of a drive for $250,000 to establish a chair at Brandeis University here in memory of Morris Hillquit, New York lawyer.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 1-- Nigeria is suffering from a severe outbreak of Asian influenza, apparently brought into the country by Moslem pilgrims returning from Mecca, Saudi Arabia.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP)--Norman Thomas, former Socialist party candidate for President, blamed the individual union member today for labor's current troubles.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 1 (AP)-- A Japanese film was acclaimed last night as the best shown in the Venice International Festival to date.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1-- Gibberellic acid, a Jack-in-theBeanstalk chemical that produces fifteen-foot-high cabbage plants and foot-long lettuce leaves, was cited to a scientific group last week as a product with an equally outsized economic future.
Two pedestrians were hit by stray police bullets in midtown last night during a five-block chase of a suspected purse snatcher.

SOME time ago a ballot was received from Charlie Johnson, the Keeper of the Keys, for candidates to the Jockey Hall of Fame, the cavalry shrine which is located at historic Pimlico in Baltimore. The voting slip was sidetracked in transit and now has become the equivalent of an absentee ballot.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 --Today marks the beginning of the new television season.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 1 (AP)--President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam left today for a ten-day official visit to Australia.
NICE, France, Sept. 1 (AP)--A mob of women greeted Frank Sinatra tonight on his arrival here to make a movie, "Kings Go Forth."
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 1 (AP)--Police Chief Frank Littlejohn dispersed today robed Ku Klux Klansmen picketing a theatre showing the motion picture "Island in the Sun."
The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is seeking to abolish the 20 per cent limit on attorney's fees in certain negligence suits against the Federal Government.
NEWBURY, N.H., Sept. 1-- Harold V. Goubert, architect, died today in New London Hospital after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP)--Y.A. Title and Hugh McElhenny clicked on a 54yard scoring pass with 1 minute 10 seconds left, giving the San Francisco Forty-Niners a 21-17 victory oyer the Cleveland Browns in a National Football League exhibition game today.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)--Plans to put Sherlock Holmes on Broadway--in a musical--rankle S.S. Roberts, master of Pembroke College, Cambridge University, and president of the Sherlock Holmes Society of London.

The taximeter--the mechanical gadget that informs a rider how much his cab trip is costing--is celebrating its fiftieth birthday here this month. Just half a century ago the clock mechanism was installed on taxis in this city.
CHICAGO, Sept, 1--Grain futures trading fell to 211 million bushels on the Board of Trade last week, compared with 265 million the preceding week and 226,604,000 a year ago.

The Brookhattans defeated the Philadelphia Ukrainians, 4--2, in an exhibition soccer game yesterday at Zerega Oval in the Bronx. In a preliminary between Metropolitan League teams, Ecuador downed Goyan, 2--0.
Now that Civil Rights legislation has been passed by Congress reconsideration of the strange jury trial provision finally adopted renews our deep concern about it.

VIENNA, Sept. 1 (AP)--H. Freeman Matthews, a career diplomat, arrived here tonight to take up his new post as United States Ambassador to Austria. His last post was Ambassador to the Netherlands. In Vienna, Mr. Matthews succeeds Llewellyn E. Thompson, who is now Ambassador to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)-- A posthumous promotion for Brig. Gen. William E. (Billy) Mitchell has received the Army's approval. This was revealed today by Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (UP)-- George Kell's two-out single in the ninth inning scored Tito Francona from second base to give the Baltimore Orioles a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.
PARIS, Sept. 1--The French Government is studying the German request to shorten the transitional period after which the Saar will become economically attached to West Germany.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 1--Robert Withington, Professor of English Language and Literature at Smith College from 1917 until his retirement in 1952, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. His age was 73.
A PSYCHIATRIST and a psychologist clashed yes terday in a lively discussion of television's influence on children.
President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil believes United States policy could make "a greater contribution to the industrialization of Brazil and the exploration of our riches."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1--There has been ample evidence in the last few days that the longawaited improvement in the steel industry is at hand. Although orders have not been ...

HEILBRONN, Germany, Sept. 1--Erich Ollenhauer, Social Democratic leader, is battling doggedly to convince West Germans that eight years of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has been too much for Germany and twelve years would be a disaster.
Herman S. Greitzer charged yesterday that the patronage system used by Tammany Hall was one of a "great many wicked things" going on under the leadership of Carmine G. De Sapio.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 1 --In Temple Emanuel here at noon today, Miss Joanna Schimmel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Schimmel of Westfield, was married to Irvin Gotlieb, lieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gotlieb of Birmingham, Ala.
COLP, Ill., Sept. 1--An attempt to effect integration of the grade-school pupils in this southern Illinois community has been met by stubborn resistance on the part of the parents of white children.

Much of the discussion of the North Atlantic alliance has centered around so or so many divisions, or such and such weapons, under the command of SHAPE, near Paris. It is natural to think of the organization as designed primarily to provide a ground defense for Western Europe.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP)-- Herb Score, a southpaw, and a rookie right-hander, Stan Pitula, were taken off the Cleveland Indians' disabled list today and put on the active roster.
"The spirit of Cain hovers like a dark cloud over the present age," the Rev. Bernard Donachie said yesterday at the 10 A.M. mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
"The Last Station," Erich Maria Remarque's first play, which was successfully put on in West Berlin last year, may be directed by Harold Clurman.

An 80-year-old recluse who was discovered unconscious in his Brooklyn apartment yesterday was found to have fiftyfour bankbooks with deposits totaling about $100,000. The books were in his pockets and sewn to the lining of his coat.
KULA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 1 (AP)--The newly independent Federation of Malaya saluted its first Paramount Ruler with a military parade today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (UP)--Karen Hantze, 14-yearold, of San Diego, won the Unied States Girls Lawn Tennis final today with a 6-3, 8-10, 6-2 victory over Gwyneth Thomas of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

A hero's welcome was given yesterday to four cadets of the Polish Air Force who fled from Poland a year ago in two stolen training planes. They were greeted first at La Guardia Airport, where they arrived by ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended Aug. 31:
CHICAGO, Sept. 1--A break in September corn featured grain trading last week. That future hit a new low of 120 .
When school bells ring this fall they may sound a little out of tune. To the school principal their ring will make him wonder whether he has enough teachers to go around.
LONDON, Sept. 1--Dr. Frederick S. Boas, authority on Elizabethan literature, died today at his home here. He was 95 years old.
Both the State Department and the Department of Justice are engaged in a ceaseless effort to answer two questions:
Net income of the VirginiaCarolina Chemical Corporation dipped to $846,380 in the fiscal year to last June 30, from $1,379,016 in fiscal 1956.
The Rev. Sydney Barr said yesterday that "far from being wrapped up in the vast universe He had created, God has time for every living thing."
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 1-- French troops crossed the Tunisian frontier from Algeria today and fought an engagement on Tunisian soil killing at least seven North Africans.

VIENNA, Sept. 2--The United Nations General Assembly session on Hungary will receive a proposal, endorsed by some Arab and Asian states, justifying the Soviet bloc's position on the Hungarian revolt, according to information reaching here today.
ALPBACH, Austria, Sept. 1 --"Coordination" was the keynote of discussions last week at the annual rally here of the European Forum.

LADENTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 1 --Ch. Icarus Duke Otto, a white miniature poodle under the control of one of the most successful handlers in the East, Jane F. Kamp, took best in show at today's Rockland County Kennel Club dog show.
A defending contrast bridge team headed by Edgar Kaplan of New York City early today won the 1957 Knickerbocker Team of Four Championship.
Erratic movement of the Canadian dollar marked the trading in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Spot pound sterling was steady while the forwards were subject to wide fluctuations.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 1--The world's small collection of ruling monarch's has a new member, but he is a king with a difference, several differences.
BOSTON, Sept. 1--A healthy 14-year-old girl gave up a kidney today in an attempt to save the life of her twin sister.
Edward J. Gresser, a vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died yesterday in Midtown Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

Although summer officially has a little time yet to run, for the Park Department it is over, at least as far as its park swimming pools are concerned. Today is the final day the pools will be in use this season.

Palm Beach Towers, a $9,000,000 apartment hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., has been leased by Towers Apartments, Inc., to Lawrence A. Wien, New York attorney and realty investor. The building was completed last January.
Thomas L. Hickey, New York Teamsters Union leader, reiterated yesterday his intention of opposing James R. Hoffa for the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 1 --Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla will return to Colombia from exile in Spain, according to reports received by the Government last night. A five-man military junta overthrew the dictator on May 10 after a tenday rebellion.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 1 (AP)--Gene Folkes of Verona, N.J., and Allan Hirsh of Montclair, N.J., downed Louis Polane of Hot Springs and Dan Ingalls of Cambridge, Mass., 4 and 3, today in a best-ball golf tournament.
Repeat performances of "The Consul" and "Separate Tables" will begin tonight at the Wollman Memorial Theatre (Central Park) and at the Music Box, respectively.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 (Reuters)-- Soviet, Polish, Czechoslovak and East German jet fighters today staged an air show at Cottbus, East Germany, the East Ger-, man news agency ADN reported.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 --A package of ten post-1948 Warner Brothers theatrical features has been cleared for television sale by three major Hollywood talent guilds.
MADISON, N.J., Sept, 2-- "Pseudo-maturity" is the word proposed by some young Europeans for the behavior of American children they came to know while Camp counselors this summer.
Johnny Antonelli, a good-hitting pitcher, stayed around long enough to smash a two-run homer that provided the Giants with the points they needed to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates...
It may be merely coincidental, but in the wake of Sal Maglie's sale to the Yankees, the Dodgers lost a double-header to the phils at Ebbets Field yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 --Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that it would release thirty-seven feature motion pictures during 1958. Four of the pictures are before the cameras. The films will be based mainly on best-selling novels and adaptations of New York stage hits.
A national shortage of qualified health personnel exists in almost all fields, according to a survey completed by the National Health Council.

Jerry Luedee, a rugged lightheavyweight from New Haven, Conn., scored a technical knockout over Freddie Mack of Brooklyn at the end of the eighth round in the main bout scheduled for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
FROBISHER BAY, Baffin Island, Canada, Aug. 22--Toughskinned young frogmen in United States Navy underwater demolition teams are doing hard diving in the frigid waters of the Arctic.

LONDON, Sept. 2--The Soviet Union announced tonight that it would begin extensive maneuvers next week in Arctic waters. The Atlantic pact powers are to hold exercises in other Arctic waters during part of the same period.
LONDON, Sept. 2--Prices of most industrial equities were firm on the Stock Exchange here today. Government securities, however, declined.

"An Evening With Kukla, Fran and Ollie" will bring the television favorites to Broadway on Nov. 21. The house will be announced later by the sponsors, Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr, producers of "Auntie Mame." Associated with them in the new project will be Beulah Zachary, producer of the video program.
Three hundred top theologians and religious leaders will begin a week-long conference on church unity today in Oberlin, Ohio. This is one of the most pressing problems of American Protestantism.

CASTLETON, Vt., Sept. 2 --Carl Sedergren, a main tenance foreman with the Vermont Marble Company, is strictly a seasonal fisherman. While he delights in angling for bass and pike, he refuses to try his luck until after Labor Day.

More than 400 persons lost their lives on the nation's highways during the Labor Day week-end. As vacationers and holiday crowds headed for home yesterday at the end of the summer vacation season, the toll of traffic fatalities mounted steadily.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2--A Washington artist put the finishing touches last week to a new "Surrender of Lord Cornwallis," done in the authentic perspective of history and the third dimension.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (U.P.)--The Milwaukee Braves took a twin bill from the Chicago Cubs today. Wes Covington and Hank Aaron each drove in six runs to pace a 23-10 opening game victory and Bob Trowbridge hurled a three-hitter for a 4-0 triumph in the second contest.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 2--Hugh Gaitskell asserted today that he was not worried about a trade union attack on the nationalization program that he and other leaders of the Labor party are sponsoring.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP)--Chevrolet is cutting further into Ford's lead in passenger car production. Output figures for the year to date show the Ford lead stands at less than 5,000 units. Two months ago, Ford led Chevrolet by nearly 28,000 units.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Liggett Gray of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Gwin Gray, to Ensign Alan Pollock Schaeffer of the Navy. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John M. Schaeffer, also of Riverside, formerly of Short Hills, N.J.
LONDON, Sept. 2--Helen Haye, believed to be Britain's oldest working actress, died in a nursing home here last night. She was 83 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 2--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has told Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, that "real progress" on world disarmament is up to the Soviet Union.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2-- Paul Hoffmann's Hother, a forty-six-foot cutter from Larchmont, racing in the Class A division, won the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race that ended today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Tuesday, Sept. 3--Gov. Orval E. Faubus sent militiamen and state police last night to Little Rock High School, where racial integration had been scheduled to start today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2-- Harold E. Stassen, departing to resume the London disarmament talks, said today that "we should be patient and persistent in these negotiations."

The battle of "West Point" has ended in victory for its fans. The filmed drama series, which had been headed for retirement, will be transferred instead from the Columbia Broadcasting System to the American Broadcasting Company and continue on the air.
A player of relative obscurity scored one of the most unexpected victories of the tennis season yesterday in the national championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

Employers' Group Associates, a Massachusetts insurance enterprise, is offering holders of its common shares the right to subscribe for 88,761 shares at $48 each on the basis of one new share for every four held.
CHICAGO Sept. 2 (AP)--Willie Shoemaker today won his third straight Washington Park Handicap by piloting Pucker Up to a three-length victory over Find.

Krupp and Eaton ... The combination of a famous German and a famous American business name conjures interesting possibilities.
A new type life insurance policy was made available yesterday for the first time to "single parents" and their children.
DACHAU, Germany, Sept. 5-- Erich Ollenhauer, Social Democratic leader, accepted a major political risk in coming here to the site of a former concentration camp today.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 5--Three arrests in integration squabbles marked the reopening of Maryland's public schools today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5--Half of the boats that were winners at the beginning of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week yesterday added victories today. There were ten from twenty classes that remained unbeaten on a brilliant sailing day of fair northwest wind.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city's streets were "cleaner than at any time in my nearly two decades of public service."
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics rose to 88.5 from 88.3 on Tuesday. The figure for Sept. 5, 1956 was 91.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept 5-- Newport Gypsy scored a length victory over Fleetwood M. in the $4,000 Kings Point pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Brainwashing is not a strange new weapon but is made up of several ordinary laws of human behavior, a group of researchers said here yesterday.
The chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Hortense Fisher Dunlap to William G. Davis Jr.
The city's Community Mental Health Board agreed yesterday to make the minutes of its meetings available to a Robert K. Christenberry, Republican candidate for Mayor.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today elaborated his views on a permanent United Nations police force.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 5--Mr. and Mrs. Bernie Mann's Riviera Wonder from Brookville triumphed in an open jumper class with Al Fiore riding as the twenty-fourth North Shore horse show opened today at the Old Field Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP)--Marines swept the top four places in the national service rifle championship today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Dollar outlays for construction reached a record $4,600,000,000 in August, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.
Under a guiding nudge from a totally unsuspected hand, the lagging Yankee pennant express switched back from dead-end sidings to the main line yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 5--Representatives of the Society of Jesus began today a conclave on questions of highest importance to the future of their order.
LONDON, Sept. 5--The West and the Soviet Union agreed today to recess the disarmament discussions, with the two sides far apart.

A ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway will be a feature of the fourteen crowded hours that Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will spend in New York Monday, Oct. 21.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 5--A group of State Legislators, historians and assorted assistants are on a sentimental journey this week. They are looking for some remains of the original Erie Canal worth preserving as "living museums" of De Witt Clinton's famous ditch of 1825.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 --Despite a published report from Rome that quoted Ingrid Bergman as denying she had been signed to star in "I Thank a Fool" for Metro-GoldwynMayer, a studio spokesman said today "as far as Metro is concerned, she will do the picture."

HONG KONG, Sept. 5--Dr. Leroy E. Burney, Surgeon General of the United States, said here today that the United States was ready to cope with a possible epidemic of Asian influenza this fall and winter.

Directors of Smith-Corona, Inc., yesterday declared the regular 45-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock for payment on Sept. 30. In addition, they voted an increase to 50 cents in the quarterly dividend to be distributed on Dec. 31.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 5-- Traditional differences in the organizational structure of Protestant churches in this country are gradually evaporating, it was reported here today.
WINTER comes to the shop window long before it finds the hillside, and, even before the smoke and yellow autumn starts, manikins on Fifth Avenue lean into the frosted gale.

The session of Congress just concluded made a creditable record in respect to legislation pertaining to the Philippines. What was done was helpful and thoughtful and good motive was obviously the prevailing sentiment.

The plumpest of the purses at Belmont Park yesterday was the $7,000 put up for the steeplechase. First money of $4,550 went to Guilford Dudley Jr.'s Hurst Park, who was half of a 19-to-5 third-choice entry.

The Giants announced yesterday that they had agreed to a system of pay-television for baseball games in their new San Francisco home. In another baseball development, a prominent financier disclosed that he had offered $5,000,000 for the Brooklyn Dodgers to keep the team here.
DETROIT, Sept. 5--The nation's new Civil Defense Administrator asserted today that the key to national survival in a nuclear attack was to prepare government at all levels for such an emergency.
Samuel Reshevsky, America's international chess ace, who won his match with Donald Byrne, the new Western champion, by a 7--3 score Wednesday night, left yesterday for his home in Spring Valley, N.Y.

A five-alarm fire in the Bronx broke out in a lumber yard last night and swept through five buildings, forcing fifty-six families to flee their homes. The fire threatened an entire city block before it was brought under control at 1:11 o'clock this morning.

Some yachtsmen would rather navigate than eat. Dozens of them will spend tomorrow on the season's final predicted log contest, a forty-two-mile affair on Long Island Sound starting and ending at the Port Washington Y.C. At stake is the national point scoring championship of power cruisers.
DALLAS, Sept. 5 (AP)--Federal judge told Dallas school officials today that they must end segregation after the Christmas holidays.

Outstanding loans to business by the larger New York City banks resumed their seasonal rise in the week ended Wednesday with a $34,000,000 increase, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the preceding week the total had dropped $150,000,000.

Gross business of The Martin Company is expected to stay steady or rise a little in the next year or two. This is likely to be the case in spite of the recent cut in defense appropriations, George M. Bunker, president, yesterday told the New York Society of Security Analysts.

It has been said that God is on the side of the heaviest battalions. The sentiment has been ascribed to Napoleon, who certainly acted upon it. Previously it had been discussed by Voltaire, who did not altogether sympathize with it.
IF THE four Pecks ever design a family crest, it should be a bolt of tweed rampant on a field of heather.
Bankers were asked yesterday to take immediate steps to help keep the nation's financial mechanism functioning in the event of a nuclear attack.
The multiple-talented Richard Whorf has been engaged to direct and design the scenery for the forthcoming dramatization of Aldous Huxley's novel "The Genius and the Goddess."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Senate investigators leveled charges today against what they called "a nefarious group of contractors." They said these contractors had dealt in bribery, delivered substandard goods, and collected "unconscionable" profits in the military uniform procurement program in the New York area.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept 5-- A guerrilla chief of the Algerian National Movement has gone over to the French side with at least 500 men, according to reliable French reports.

The Buenos Aires inter-American economic conference ended Wednesday and the customary stocktaking is under way. It will require some time to assess the results, but it is a fairly safe prediction that the decision of greatest importance was the endorsement of a Latin-American common market.
DETROIT, Sept. 5--The National Urban League asked President Eisenhower today to use his authority to end defiance of the Federal Government by Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas.
Two Queens detectives wound up a month of ice cream sodas yesterday with the arrest of five youths accused of causing $35,000 damage to thirty-five cars and trucks.
ORADELL, N.J., Sept. 5-- Dr. Charles T. Sibley, a retired physician, whose hobby was bird-watching, died yesterday in his home, 818 Midland Road, after a long illness. His age was 83.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5--The Tito regime banned today the recent book by Milovan Djilas excoriating Communist rule as exploitation of the workers and peasants by a new class of tyrants.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5--"The Seven Lively Arts," new Columbia Broadcasting System television program, will devote two shows next year to aspects of one of the contemporary lively arts--motion pictures.
TORONTO, Sept. 5--A contingent of Soviet explorers is due to leave for Antarctica this month to make a renewed attempt to establish an outpost at the "pole of inaccessibility."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- The United States decided today to fly arms to Jordan. The shipments will begin next week from depots in Europe.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 5-- Senator William F. Knowland temporarily diverted his fire today from the Governor of California to the Governor of Arkansas.
Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said yesterday that the situation in the Middle East was much better now than a year ago.

The J.I. Case Company operated in the black in the third quarter ended July 31. This improved trend and an increase of 23 per cent in sales enabled the farm equipment producer to cut its loss for the nine months this year by $3,409,584, compared with the similar period a year ago.
ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 5 (UP)--Craig Gieseke of Beach Haven, N.J., took the lead today as the international championship regatta of the Comet Class opened on wind-swept Sandy Hook Bay.

The Board of Education of the North Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District 9 declined yesterday to go through with the sale of $9,397,000 of bonds on terms stipulated by the best of three offers submitted at public sealed bidding.

VIENNA, Va., Sept. 5--Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Lawless 3d, newlywed homeowners of less than one month, were certified by the Government today as the country's fifty millionth household.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP)--International developments reverberated on the Board of Trade last week and as a result grain and soybean futures ended higher than a week earlier.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 8-- The first airlift of arms will arrive in Jordan tomorrow in a dramatic move by the United States to bolster its Middle Eastern allies against any Soviet-inspired aggression.

Althea Gibson won a title and made a new acquaintance yesterday at Forest Hills. She took the United States tennis championship and met the United States Vice President.

Albania, the smallest of the Balkan states, is a rugged mountain fastness on the Adriatic Sea.

The entire blockfront on the south side of West 170th Street from Cromwell to Inwood Avenues in the Bronx has been sold by Peter I. Feinberg.

Art of both the realistic and abstract schools yesterday attracted about 20,000 persons to the seventh annual Staten Island Outdoor Art Show. Men in Bermuda shorts and pig-tailed girls viewed the work of ninetysix amateur and professional artists.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 (AP)--Seven Governors and approximately fifty other state and local officials will meet this month to discuss problems arising from the rapid growth of metropolitan areas in the Northeast.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 8--A leading European theologian said tonight that a "burning desire" for Christian unity was spreading over the world.
The steamship charter market continued weak last week both in rates and volume, with all signs pointing to a continuance of this plight for some months.
A MOUSSE, as defined in Webster's Collegiate Dic tionary, is a frozen dessert of sweetened, flavored whipped cream or thin cream and gelatin.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Pirates hammered four Philadelphia pitchers for twelve hits today to trim the Phillies, 6--2, in the second game of a doubleheader, after dropping the opener, 7--4.
GENEVA, Sept. 8--Western Europe is increasingly skeptical of monetary and fiscal policy as a means of halting inflation, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.
TORONTO, Sept. 8 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs scored a 4-3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today to capture their third International League pennant in four years.

A balding man has a certain kewpie doll flavor that endears him to the opposite sex. But to a woman, thinning hair is a tragedy that cannot be repaired.
A top salesman will help the Sales Executives Club of New York mark its twenty-fifth anniversary today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 9 --The Federal District Court ordered the United States Government today to seek an injunction against the Governor of Arkansas to end his interference with racial integration in the schools.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9-- Maine residents voted overwhelmingly today to discard their "early bird" state election date and cast ballots with the rest of the nation in November, 1960.

An eleventh-hour appeal by Mayor Wagner last night averted the threat of a strike by 400 toll collectors and traffic control officers employed by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The walk-out had been scheduled to start this morning.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 9-- Hermann Kastner, a former East German Deputy Premier who had sought and received political asylum in West Germany last October, died in Munich two days ago. His age was 70.

The Girls' Club of New York will benefit from an evening's entertainment, "A Night at The Lambs," on Nov. 15 at the Lambs clubhouse, 128 West Forty-fourth Street. Mrs. Ralph K. Robertson is honorary chairman and Mrs. John C. McCauley Jr. is chairman of the benefit.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 9 --Billy Joe Patton, the flamboyant golfer from Morganton, N.C., joined his Walker Cup team-mates today in a parade through the first round of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship today.

The Greenwich Village Association voiced opposition last night to the proposal of Borough President Hulan E. Jack for a four-lane, forty-eightfoot-wide highway through Washington Square, The surface road would connect lower Fifth Avenue and West Broadway.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 9--Advocates of ready-made plans for the organic union of North American Protestantism were rebuked today for over-zealousness.

Former President Harry S. Truman yesterday interpreted the recent Wisconsin Senate election as representing a trend that presaged more Democratic victories in Congressional and state elections next year.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 9 --Following is the text of a statement issued here today by Gov. Orval E. Faubus criticizing Federal Judge Ronald N. Davies:

A deep and bitter split within the American Communist party has been brought into the open by John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker.
It's now possible to make a complete physical check-up of the inner workings of complex industrial engines.
The California state government and three local government subdivisions announced yesterday plans for borrowing $83,900,000 this month and next.

Miss Elinor Jane Wohl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Wohl of Lawrence, L.I., was married here last evening to Norman Lawrence Brickell. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Jules Brickell of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Mr. Brickell.

New Yorkers have the opportunity and responsibility today, in the primary election, to pass judgment upon the designations made for public office by their political parties' leadership, There are also some contests for party positions, both in Democratic and Republican

An official investigation is under way into connections between the Nassau Management Company, Inc., and employes of several city agencies. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa ordered yesterday a halt of city, payments to the company until the completion of the inquiry by Commissioner of Investigation Charles H. Tenney.

NO sooner had the brilliant pitching career of Lefty Gomez ended than the Singular One was asked to enter tain troops overseas. This was during the early days of the war. The zip had gone from the Gomez fast ball and the crackle from his curve. Only his wit remained share.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- Savings, in the sense ordinarily used by the average citizen, rose by $8,000,000,000 in the first half of this year, the sharpest rise in a decade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--Governor Faubus of Arkansas made three statements in his television interview that illustrate why his action in calling out the National Guard presents to the Federal Government one of the most difficult issues of law and tactics ever raised in the ...
August's market decline apparently went unheeded by many buyers of mutual fund shares, Reports from a wide list of the open-end investment companies indicate heavy buying by more people.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9--An antitrust suit brought eleven years ago by the Zenith Radio Corporation against the Radio Corporation of America and others was settled in United States District Court here today.

Enrolled voters will have an opportunity today to put their stamp of approval on party choices for candidates in the November election or to express a preference in contested nominations. In addition, party committeemen and district leaders will be elected in Manhattan and the Bronx.
Herman Becker, motion picture theatre operator and former vaudeville manager, died on Sunday at his home, 25 Central Park West, after a long illness. His age was 66.
REHOVOT, Israel, Sept. 9-- Leading nuclear physicists from many lands met here today to discuss their latest research into the nucleus of the atom.
TIRANA, Albania. World War II has never really ended in Albania.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 9-- (UP)--The Syrian Government accused the United States tonight of sending warships and possibly planes close to Syrian territory in an "open challenge" to this Middle Eastern nation.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 9 (Reuters)--West Germany's Minister for Economic Cooperation today opposed pricing up the Deutsch mark as a way to cut the country's large payments surplus. Instead, he called for more dollar exports as one measure.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 (AP)-- Two old-timers and Ted Atkinson, one of the nation's top present-day riders, today won places in the National Jockeys' Hall of Fame.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 9--A special report to the United Nations said today that the reign of terror in Hungary has been continued and accelerated during the last five months. It said that present conditions surpassed in ruthlessness ...

Mrs. Natalie de Lipski Rerberg, head of the New York Public Library's Russian Collection for twenty-eight years, died of cancer Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 9--Soviet vetoes today barred South Korea and South Vietnam from membership in the United Nations.

THE classic example of national panic induced by a radio broadcast--the night Orson Welles presented his own Americanized dramatization of the H.G. Wells novel, "War of the Worlds"--was the subject last night of highly interesting documentary play on "Studio One" over Channel 2.

New York City has the pleasure again of being host to the United States Conference of Mayors, which is holding a three-day meeting. While New York is the largest of American cities, its problems do not differ greatly except in size from those of other municipalities.

Marcus Heiman, long a theatre manager and former executive vice president of the KeithAlbee-Orpheum Corporation that once operated about 250 theatres, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.
Key youth workers in high hazard areas in the city yesterday opened a week of discussion. They hope to find a clinical formula for the prevention and cure of juvenile delinquency.
The 1957-58 school year got off to a varied start yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 9-- An official spokesman said today that the latest Soviet note on German reunification was an attempt to influence the results of Sunday's election.

SEATTLE, Sept. 10--A "stopHoffa" coalition of three candidates for the presidency of the Teamsters union appeared to be a prospect today. The candidates carried their plans before the leadership of the Western Conference of Teamsters.

NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10--Law enforcement officers were in complete control today at this city's all-white high school. Attempted entry by six Negro students yesterday stirred a measure of nearviolence at the school.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 10--Mrs. Marion French Overman of South Orange, widow of Neill P. Overman, was married this afternoon to Ernest Clayton Johnson Jr. of West Orange and Buck Hills Falls, Pa.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 10--George O'Day, representing the Massachusetts Bay Yacht Racing Union, today added a victory and a fourth-place finish to yesterday's triumph for a lead of 5 points in the sixth annual North American senior sailing championship for the Mallory Cub.
United States business men were urged yesterday to become better trading partners with people in southeast Asia by Hans H. Bohlmann, export manager of the Seamless Rubber Company.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 10 (AP)--The Cabinet met in an urgent session today to discuss what the Syrian Government calls anti-Syrian provocation by the United States. Leftist newspapers demanded general mobilization and martial law.

HEAVENS, Henri Bendel, how you have changed! This grand old store on Fiftyseventh Street now has a new face, new personality and new clothes. Everything about it seems fresh: the decor, the merchandise, even the bandboxstriped awning over the front door.
PARIS, Sept. 10--In an effort to stave off inflation, the French Government is asking the trade unions to put off most of their wage demands for six months.
REHOVOT, Israel, Sept. 10 --Rays emanating from the nucleus of the atom have shed new light on the inner structure of this mysterious stronghold of the cosmos.

Lawrence A. Audrain, editor of Print, a bi-monthly magazine devoted to the graphic arts, died of a circulatory ailment Monday in University Hospital. He was 47 years old, and lived at 124 East Thirty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Efforts by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter the field of private radio communications are being strongly opposed by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 10--Mr. and Mrs. William Annibali of Lawrence gave a dinner dance tonight at the Rockaway Hunting Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Luciana Anna Maria Annibali.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10--India urged the United Nations Disarmament Commission today to expedite its report to the 1957 session of the General Assembly, which will start next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Following is the State Department's transcript of the record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:

Massachusetts expects to offer $65,000,000 of one to twenty-year highway, flood and capital outlay bonds Oct. 15, John Kennedy, state treasurer, announced yesterday. The offering is subject to approval of the Governor and the Governor's council.

PARIS, Sept. 10--The search for oil in the French Sahara received new interest with the announcement tonight that five United States and French banking and petroleum companies have joined together for prospecting purposes.
VIENNA, Sept. 10--The Hungarian Government denied today that Archbishop Jozsef Groesz, acting head of the Roman Catholic Church in Hungary, was under arrest.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 10-- Dr. Edward S. Lamar, chief scientist of the Navy Bureau of Ordnance, urged tonight that scientists study the fish's method of propulsion.

Louis Rozman, a partner in Louis Rozman Co., 468 Fourth Avenue, cotton converters, and a benefactor of numerous Jewish causes, died Monday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. Mr. Rozman, who was 75 years old, resided at 8717 Twenty-first Avenue, Brooklyn.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 10-- The first step toward the formation of a Ghanian national shipping line was taken here today in an agreement signed by the Ghana Government and representatives of the Zim Israeli Navigation Company, ltd.

The chairman of the United Nations Security Council announced a count of votes Tuesday afternoon. Ten of the Council's eleven members had been in favor of admitting South Vietnam to the United Nations. One member was in opposition.
The Yankees and Indians spent 2 hours 30 minutes last night trying to get the opener of their two-game series into the records. But it was no go.
Two elephant seals have been banished from the Aquarium for picking on the baby walrus, the only one in captivity in North America.
PARIS, Sept. 10--Premier Maurice Bourges-Maunoury today called a special session of Parliament to deal with the Algerian problem. It will meet Sept. 24.

Increased operating costs were responsible for an 11.2 per cent drop in earnings of Montgomery Ward Co. in the six months ended July 31, compared with the profit a year earlier, John A. Barr, chairman, reported yesterday.
HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 10--Leaders of the German Reich party appealed last night to 500 followers to vote for a "rejuvenated, unified fatherland serving neither Washington nor Moscow."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The Government indicated in an official report today that the capital boom was leveling. A private source gave figures bearing out the Government's findings.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10--Behind closed doors Indonesian civil and military leaders met here today to try to find a formula to solve the "present chaotic situation" in the archipelago republic.
We remember too vividly the long fight waged to establish an independent Department of Air Pollution Control in New York City to look with favor on any proposal to chip away at that agency's powers.

Opponents of the Lincoln Square redevelopment will set up a picket line this morning in front of City Hall, where the City Planning Commission will conduct a public hearing on final plans for the $200,000,000 slum clearance project.

The size of the mysterious spiral-shaped structures that control the reproduction of living cells in all organisms, from tiny bacteria up to man himself, reportedly has been measured for the first time.
After watching from the sidelines, leading Sales finance companies have been forced to join the parade of short-term borrowers who have raised interest rates they pay to investors.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 10 (U.P.)--The University of Florida football team had to call off its season opener with the University of California at Los Angeles today because of an influenza epidemic that had felled some sixty-five Florida players since the squad reported Aug. 30.
Another public offering of bonds of the Kingdom of Belgium--the second since 1954--is on the market today to finance improvement of inland waterways and other public works.

George E. Halpern, superintendent of Lebanon Hospital, until his retirement in 1941, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 330 East Seventy-ninth Street and in Miami Beach, Fla.

The crisis now besetting the remnants of the Communist party in this country has been revealed by the events of the last few days. The party's membership, including the bulk of such working-class strength it ever had, has deserted it in droves and the best guess its leaders can make of its strength is only 10,000.
Leon Benoit, retired president of the old Egg-Safety Carton Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 200 East End Avenue. His age was 79.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10-- The prosecution in the libel trial of Confidential magazine said today that the publication's transcontinental operation was essentially a multi-million-dollar enterprise of one New York family.
Census takers in April skipped 27 per cent of 50,800 city families queried recently by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, the association declared yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 10--A new record club, whose founders say they have an unusual repertory and method of manufacture, will soon begin operations in the United States.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10 --The United States Government began court action today against the Governor of Arkansas.
TORONTO, Sept. 10--The electric potential of the air we breathe has decreased more than sixfold in the years since the first nuclear explosions, it was reported here today.
Candidates with party organization backing swamped their rivals yesterday in all primary contests within the city for nominations to public office.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The United States Tariff Commission took the unusual step today of recommending an import quota in an "escape clause" case.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Secretary of State Dulles praised today the work of the London disarmament conference, which broke up unsuccessfully last week.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 10--The golfing adventures of Billy Joe Patton in the United States Golf Association's amateur championship ended in the second round today.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP)--German bonds gained strength today in a busy trading session that dominated an otherwise depressed London stock market.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10-- A victory by a mare unable to win in fifty-one starts, the first claim of the meeting and Frank Safford, a 48-year-old driver from Southern Pines, N.C., all figured in interesting developments at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
FOR its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Royal Ballet last night again presented its fulllength "Sleeping Beauty," though with changes of cast in three of its leading roles.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10--The United States urged the General Assembly today to keep the Hungarian question "in the forefront" of discussion.

BRINDISI, Italy, Sept. 10 (Reuters)--About 1,200 policemen Patrolled tense villages in the wine-rich "heel" of Italy tonight following week-end riots in which three were killed and about forty injured.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) --Senator Richard L. Neuberger said today he would introduce legislation barring the use of the National Guard as "the personal army or storm-troop unit of a Governor."

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Sept. 10--The campaign for the Governorship gained momentum tonight as Gov. Robert B. Meyner met his Republican opponent, Malcolm S. Forbes, here in the first of a series of nine public debates.

The Presbyterian Home for Aged Women will benefit from the Nov. 8 preview performance at the Morosco Theatre of "Time Remembered," starring Helen Hayes, Susan Strasberg and Richard Burton.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 10 --Sidney R. Siben, 47 years old, one of Suffolk County's most popular trial lawyers in the last ten years, was arraigned here today on a charge of "soliciting business on behalf of an attorney"--himself.

The first report card is already in concerning what most grammar-school boys wore to school on opening day.

A SURPLUS of authorities, with not enough time for any one of them to speak at meaningful length, handicapped the debut last night of the new discussion program entitled "The Big Issue," seen at 7:30 o'clock over Channel 4. Two speakers, three expert questioners and a moderator can make for a rather congested thirty minutes of video.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 10 --Two false bombing reports and student demonstrations marked the local school scene today.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 10-- Two Democratic and two Republican contests in Westchester were settled in the primaries today.
Twenty artists will make their debuts with the New York City Opera during the company's fall season, beginning Oct. 9, it was announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, director of the company.

The National Broadcasting Company has obtained a fiveyear television and radio contract to broadcast the annual Sugar Bowl football game in New Orleans. In recent years the event had been a feature of the American Broadcasting Company network.

THERE being a slight strain in diplomatic relations between Sugar Ray Robinson and this column, all usual channels of communication and all normal means of gathering information have been cut off. Border guards have been posted outside Sugar Ray's training headquarters at Long Pond Inn while coastal batteries have been alerted along Greenwood Lake. At least that's what was reported by a scouting patrol.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10--Ireland suggested today that the United States and the Soviet Union withdraw their armed forces from Central Europe.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 10 --Auctions of foreign currency for importers were resumed here today, ending a twenty-sevenday interruption of imports into Brazil.

The country and the world are now witness to an extraordinary test of strength between the Governor of one of the sovereign states and the Government of the United States. There can be only one outcome, and it is as inevitable as the Union is indestructible.

Despite a 2-0 victory in the final qualifying round, the United States failed to gain a berth in the championship phase of the women's international chess tournament at Emmen, according to a report received yesterday through Amsterdam news sources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) --Hope for personal income-tax relief by next year was voiced today by Representative Jere Cooper, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which initiates tax legislation.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10--Lester Cowan is preparing to re-enter the Hollywood production arena after an absence of seven years.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Henry Aaron and Eddie Mathews belted consecutive homers in the fourth inning tonight as the league-leading Milwaukee Braves gained a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10-- Lebanon has told the United States she would stand with Syria against any attempt to change Syria's Government by force, it was reported here today.
A leading economist said yesterday that the nation had experienced a "serious slowdown in consumption growth" this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that gains in crop prospects during August promised to make 1957 production the third largest of record.

New buying, manufacturer purchasing for price fixing and short covering pushed cocoa futures to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Light stop-loss buying was touched off during the session.
Cash savings, the figures on which are compiled twice a year by the Home Loan Bank Board, increased by $8 billion in the first half of 1957, the sharpest rise in a decade.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 10-- Jordan has no intention of interfering, in Syria despite the "unfortunate" impression created by the arrival of United States arms in Jordan.
TRENTON, Sept. 10--Increasing Democratic factionalism in Hudson County threatens to hold to a minimum any majority Gov. Robert B. Meyner might be able to win in his bid for re-election Nov. 5.
Four families had a homecoming to their old uptown neighborhood yesterday. They moved into bright new apartments built on the site of their former slum dwellings.

TWO of this month's most expertly written novels are short enough so that I had time to read them both in the in terval between writing last Monday's and today's columns. The first, "Angel," by Elizabeth Taylor, is the sixth novel by one of the most professionally accomplished women novelists in Great Britain.

A small missionary with an irresistible grin and a face gleaming like a new copper penny arrived in New York yesterday from the jungles of Borneo. He is Paul Breman, 4 years old, whose father was chief of a naked, head-hunting tribe of Dyaks in western Borneo.

The Liberal party charged yesterday that the Transit Authority's proposal to sell its three rapid transit power plants would be "inimical to the best interests of the city and its people." The plants would be sold to the Consolidated Edison Company.

The thirty-five-room mansion of Mrs. William C. Woodward Sr. at 9 East Eighty-sixth Street has been sold to the Town Club in an all-cash transaction exceeding the dwelling's assessed valuation of $320,000.
LONDON, Sept. 10--Charles Chaplin was here today beating the publicity drums for his latest motion picture, "A King in New York," which will have its world premiere here Thursday.

Directors of the Maracaibo Oil Exploration Corporation yesterday declared a cash dividend of $1 a share and an additional $7.50 a share payable in 6 per cent subordinated debentures, both to holders of record of Sept. 23.

The Health Department's advisory committee on influenza declared yesterday that it did not know enough about the effectiveness of Asian influenza vaccine "at this time" to urge its use by the general public.

The Mayor of Milwaukee accused state governments yesterday of failing to deal effectively with the problems of metropolitan growth. He said there was more and more talk of creating new states directly under Federal control out of such areas.
Four promotions on the passenger department staff of Furness, Withy Co., involving men with a combined service of 100 years, were announced yesterday by James N. Findlay, passenger traffic manager.
NEWPOPT, R.I., Sept. 10-- President Eisenhower counseled "patience" today in dealing with the tense school integration dispute in Little Rock, Ark.
The firm of Geisinger Germain has sold to C. Dorn the five-story apartment house at 1131 Elder Avenue, the Bronx. The structure on a plot 100 by 100 feet, is assessed at $130,000.
NEWARK, Sept. 10--A plan for a $400,000,000 rapid transit system linking New York and New Jersey was coldly received in New Jersey today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press)--United States control over Canadian industry increased in the first half of 1957 as Canada chalked up new deficits in her foreign trade of goods and services, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
TWO highly individual artists are represented in the first shows of the new season at the Museum of Modern Art, opening to the public today.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Robert K. Christenberry, the Republican candidate for Mayor, agreed yesterday that "the safety of the City of New York" was a major campaign issue.

TIRANA, Albania. A shoeshine costs a dollar in Tirana, but this is the least of Albania's worries. Not many Albanians shine their shoes. In fact, many of them go barefoot or wear straw or wooden clogs.

A non-exclusive cross-licensing agreement on computers and other electronic data processing machines has been entered into by the Radio Corporation of America and the International Business Machines Corporation.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 10-- Following is the text of a message to the Protestant churches of North America adopted today at the conference on church unity:
Imre Nagy's story of events leading to the Hungarian revolt last autumn will be published here tomorrow.
Two 17-year-old Brooklyn boys were arrested yesterday for swindling $12,110 from the Allied Stores Corporation with forged travel expense vouchers.
The Appellate Division unanimously reinstated yesterday an anti-picketing injunction against strikers at a Bronx plastics plant.
Starting at 8 o'clock tonight, "Carousel" will begin to spin once more at the City Center.
The National Labor Relations Board has certified the International Longshoremen's Association as the bargaining agent for office workers' of the French Line in the Port of New York.

HARTFORD, Sept. 10--A suggestion that a Cabinet post of "urban affairs" be established in the highway and housing planning field was advanced today at a highway conference. The proposal was made by Carl Feiss, former chief of planning and engineering of the Urban Reneway Administration.
WHAT is known as the United Nations mood of Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller has now compelled him to intercede in behalf of those trying to keep the Brooklyn Dodgers here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, indicated today that the United States could perfect the intermediate range 1,500mile ballistic missile in about a year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--, How severe will be the lasting impact of the last week's crisis in Little Rock, Ark., on the progress of peaceful school integration in the South?

Stocks yesterday fell below the 1957 low set in February. With prices drifting down for most of two months in light trading, the professionals had been holding their collective breath for just such a development.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The Washington Broadcasting Company announced plans today to offer this city pay-television programs over a closedwire circuit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10--An exploratory hearing seeking to determine possible state jurisdiction over pay television was held here today by the Interim Committee on Public Utilities of the Assembly. No concrete course of action was set.
State Supreme Court Justice Walter A. Lynch, Democratic candidate for Governor in 1950, died yesterday at his summer home, 139 Beach 135th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens. His age was 63.
Many socially prominent men and women are serving as members of the benefit committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday it had developed a new, easily fabricated stainless steel able to withstand the searing high temperatures caused by air friction at aircraft speeds up to 2,700 miles an hour.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10--A first-division finish by the Giants appeared more remote than ever after Bill Rigney's club bowed, 4--1, to Brooks Lawrence and the fourth-place Redlegs at Crosley Field tonight. The setback, charged to Johnny Antonelli, sent the Giants, who are sixth, five and one-half games behind the Redlegs.
The city's youth gangs are not so bad as they have been painted, the Youth Board conference on juvenile delinquency was told yesterday.

The Rev. Reginald A. McKernan, pastor of St. Edmund's Roman Catholic Church, Ocean Avenue and Avenue T, Brooklyn, died there yesterday. He was 60 years old. His parish included an elementary school and a girls' high school.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10--Gov. Orval E. Faubus said at a news conference late this afternoon that the National Guard would remain on duty at Central High School here despite Federal court action against him today.
PARIS lost its waist but found its legs. It also rediscovered its youth.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10-- Nassau County Republican leaders today abandoned their plan to renominate in town conventions their party's candidates for local offices selected in today's primary.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10--President Tito of Yugoslavia strongly supported today Poland's claim to the Oder-Neisse lands taken from Germany at the end of World War II.

COOS BAY, Ore., Sept, 10 (AP)--A Norwegian freighter smashed broadside into a big Army dredge tonight, killing at least two members of the fifty-man crew of the dredge. The dredge sunk in Coos Bay channel.

In North Carolina there is a "research triangle." It extends from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill to Duke University in Durham and North Carolina State College at Raleigh.

DEAL, N.J., Sept. 10--Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, the defending champion, paced the opening-round in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship today. She scored a 6-and-5 victory over Mrs. David Dickson of Jumping Brook at the Deal Golf Club.

Fifty thousand rush-hour subway riders were delayed up to seventy minutes yesterday morning when a Manhattan-bound Seventh Avenue IRT train broke down south of the Wall Street station.
MELBOURNE, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Japan has purchased 57,500 tons of Australian wheat, since the signing of the Japanese trade agreement in July.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 10--President Eisenhower's Council on Youth Fitness decided today that the "physical erosion" of youth was serious enough to require a countrywide radio-television talk by the President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would give "sympathetic consideration" to any Indian request for economic assistance.

Former President Harry S. Truman played harbor pilot and practical joker yesterday. In rapid succession he steared a Coast Guard cutter, greeted two incoming friends in the Upper Bay and devised a hoax for one.

Johnny Ruane gave an exhibition of game and skillful riding to score with Henry Lewis Floral Girl at Belmont Park yesterday. The young Irish jockey guided the daughter of Noble Hero to success by more than four lengths over Heart's Desire in the six-furlong feature event.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, came to the defense yesterday of William S. Lebwohl, counsel to the authority, whose real estate investments are under investigation by the city.
