CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Grains and soybeans, lower in early dealings today, closed steady to firm as traders sought to even up commitments in advance of the Government's September crop report. The report was issued after the close of trading.

LUDLOW, N.B., Sept. 10-- An angler who gets a strike while fishing for salmon is like a man who talks to himself for several hours and suddenly gets a loud, clear answer. Neither knows whether to believe it or not.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The first of six oil companies presented its case today for relief from the restrictions of the so-called voluntary program to curb oil imports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Employment decreased by 800,000 in August from the July total, partly because of an "especially sharp" drop in the number of farm workers, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The divorced wife of Gen. Pal Maleter, leader of the Hungarian forces in the revolt last fall, petitioned the United Nations today to intercede with Soviet and Hungarian authorities on his behalf.
The author of the most controversial labor-relations program in a major industry has been relieved of operating responsibility by the General Electric Company.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 10--An explosion early today heavily damaged a $500,000 newly integrated school here. The Hattie Cotton grammar school was empty at the time of the blast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The United States Information Agency is giving its overseas audience a full, balanced report on Southern integration troubles, officials of the agency said today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10--Walt Alston unveiled two of his new Dodger pitchers at Wrigley Field today, but only one of them showed any promise of helping the club.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 10--A series of public trials will be held soon in Indian Kashmir and the prosecution will be talking as much to the United Nations Security Council as to the judge on the bench.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Sept. 10--Drury W. Cooper, a leading patent attorney and former head of the New York law firm of Cooper, Dunham, Dearborn Henninger, died here today in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 85 years old.
In May, 1956, a team of Swiss mountain climbers reached the top of Lhotse, the highest unconquered peak in the world, then went on to conquer Everest twice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Secretary of State Dulles tempered today earlier official United States expressions of alarm over Syria.
The hopes of Brooklyn Baseball fans soared yesterday when Nelson A. Rockefeller spurred a drive to keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn.

The New York Durning Agency of the Mutual Life Insurance Company has leased the third floor of the office building being constructed at 405 Park Avenue. The insurance agency will move from 60 East Fortysecond Street in November.
TAKE a cup of heavy cream, a half cup of cold water and an ice cube, whip them up in an electric blender and voila-- you have the sweetest, freshest, most delicately flavored butter imaginable.

Net income of North American newsprint producers in the first half of 1957 averaged 22 per cent below earnings in the corresponding period last year, according to a survey by the Newsprint Information Committee.

The Director of Defense Mobilization told the United States Conference of Mayors here yesterday that in the event of atomic attack most of the real work of survival would fall on their city organizations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Opponents of toll charges on the St. Lawrence Seaway are guilty of "a breach of good faith," a, hearing of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation's toll committee was told today.
New York longshoremen yesterday demanded and won a promise of special sick-pay benefits as the price of exposing themselves to possible infection by Asian influenza.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --The Detroit Tigers swept a double-header from the Washington Senators tonight, 3-0 and 12-2. Jim Bunning pitched his first major league shutout and hit his first major league homer and Al Kaline slammed his twenty-second homer in the first game.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 11-- Nassau County Republicans voted incumbent committeemen out of party office in two election districts at the primary election polls yesterday. The upsets came in West Hempstead's Seventeenth Election District and Lynbrook's Eighteenth Election District.
THE nearest thing to an Eastern bazaar this side of Gibraltar is the National Homefurnishings Show, which opens today in the Coliseum.
Stockholders in the Federation Bank and Trust Company will vote Oct. 8 on a proposed subscription offering of $2,496,900 in new shares.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Sept. 11--Dr. Coryell Clark, a physician and surgeon here for the last fifty-four years, died yesterday at the Julia L. Butterfield Memorial Hospital of cancer of the lung. His age was 77.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The State Department said today that France had agreed to allow Pan American Airways to make a first flight on its new route from Los Angeles to Paris via Frobisher Bay on Baffin Island, Canada.
ROME, Sept. 11--Pope Plus XII has called for an extension of the work of the Legion of Decency from motion pictures to radio and television and for making such supervision of these media world-wide.

The French National Assembly has been summoned to meet later this month to dead with the Algerian problem. This means that the proposed new statute for Algeria is virtually ready and that Premier Bourges-Maunoury is fairly certain he can win its passage.
YENGEMA, Sierra Leone, Sept. 11 (Reuters)--Police "bush commandos" backed by British Army units today raided Koidu, an illicit diamond-mining boom town. It lies in the heart
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 11--Jawaharlal Nehru returned to the Vale of Kashmir today to receive one of the warmest welcomes he has had in a decade as the leader of independent India.
Robert K. Christenberry told a group of hotel men here last night that his goal as the Republican candidate for Mayor was "to run the phonies out of our city's govern ment." In his first major
William Dewey Loucks, a retired lawyer who had specialized in the field of hotel reorganization, died yesterday at his residence in the Park Lane Hotel. He was 77 years old.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP)--The grain market today suffered its sharpest decline in months, influenced by a Government report that forecast near-record crops this year.
The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., objected yesterday to being called "the hate crowd" by the New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower received what was called an "encouraging" report today from the Secretary of Agriculture on a continuing upward trend of farm prices.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 (AP)--The state Education Commissioner declared today that "a new crisis in education" appeared to be in the making as New York public schools entered the fall term.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 11 (UP) --Hank Foiles hit a home run in the third inning today and singled across a run in the ninth for a 2-1 triumph by the last-place Pittsburgh Pirater over the Milwaukee Braves Warren Spahn, trying for his twentieth victory, was the losing pitcher.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (UP)--Jim Rivera and Bill Fischer kept the Chicago White Sox's slim pennant hopes alive today as they combined to beat the Boston Red Sox, 4--1 in an eleveninning thriller.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 2 points (10 cents a bale) up yesterday.
A 28-year-old honor policeman last night shot and killed a young man who, he said, had stabbed him in the stomach with no apparent motive.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Some measure of prosperity returned to the Dodgers at Wrigley Field today when they outscored the cubs, 9--1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower reluctantly signed today a new immigration bill that fell far short of the recommendations he had made last January.

The National Administrative Committee of the Communist party in the United States has acknowledged that the party is passing through a period of deep crisis. But the committee professed to see better times ahead for American Communists.

An issue of $110,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Sperry Rand Corporation bearing interest of 5 per cent and due in 1982 was placed on the market yesterday by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.
The Dow Chemical Company plans to continue its "vigorous expansion," a stockholders' meeting was told yesterday in Midland, Mich. Outlays in the
WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 11 (UP)--Mexico gained the lead on the first day of the International Tuna Cup match today on a 655-pound catch by Juan Diaz de la Torre.

The Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement will receive the proceeds of a theatre party on Nov. 7. Mrs. Otto Crouse, benefit chairman, has announced that the settlement has taken over the performance that eve
A flood of suggestions for coping with juvenile delinquency was poured into the record yesterday at the third day of the City Youth Board's forum on the subject.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11--Britain today accused the Soviet Union, rather than the present Hungarian regime, of responsibility for "brutal repression" in Hungary.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 11 --In one of the longest extra hole matches in recent championships Willie Turnesa lost a decision at the twenty-fourth hole to 43-year-old Jack Penrose of Miami Beach in the fourth round of the United States amateur golf tournament today.

HAVANA, Sept. 11--At least two naval officers have been dishonorably discharged as a result of last week's revolt at the Cienfuegos naval base. At least three other officers have been relieved of their posts and will be reassigned.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 11-- The seventh International Students Conference opened today at Ibadan University here in Nigeria's western region capital.

TODAY, 4:30 P.M.: A film, "The Fallen Eagle" will be shown at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Admission is free. Other films will be presented at the same hour tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday.
ALBANY, Sept. 11--Governor Harriman named a committee today to consider "proposed changes and improvements" in the law covering labor union welfare funds.
Next year's sales of sound reproduction instruments, other than radio and television, would exceed $1 billion, James M. Toney predicted yesterday. Mr. Toney is vice

After two years of protracted negotiations, the Holland-America Line and the city yesterday reached an agreement on the construction of an $18,723,000 passenger and cargo terminal on the Hudson River at West Houston Street.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11--The conviction of five Communists for conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government by force was reversed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11 --While the battle to maintain segregation rages in cities south of here, this week Louisville quietly entered its second year of school integration.

A 22-year-old Brooklyn waitress was held in $50,000 bail as a material witness in Kings County Court yesterday even though she had the written promise of a police lieutenant that she would not have to testify in a murder case.

Three debutantes, the Misses Daphne Fairbanks, Wendy Vanderbilt and Sandra Topping were honored here last night.

Bayou of the Claiborne Farm won the $30,600 Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The daughter of Hill Prince had to come from 'way back, but she did quite handily under the competent guidance of Eddie Arcaro.
The explosive racial situation in Little Rock, Ark, has produced repercussions at performances of "South Pacific" at Westbury, L.I.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 11 --Meadow Imp, a 5-year-old mare who is partial to trotting, won the featured $4,000 Bedminister-Fowler Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday that subscriptions and single tickets for its 1957-58 concerts in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium would go on sale to the public Oct. 1. Until that date, sales are limited to Museum members.
Lavish praise and indignant criticism were alternately heaped upon the $200,000,000 Lincoln Square project yesterday at a crowded public hearing before the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Public Health Service today reiterated its position that Asian influenza vaccine should be widely used among the general population.
Imports of crude oil and refined products rose to a new high in the week ended last Friday. According to the American Petroleum Institute, they averaged 1,795,200 barrels a
Nelson A. Rockefeller's efforts to keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn produced political crossfires yesterday in the mayoralty campaign.

Ray M. Gidney, United States Controller of the Currency, has given preliminary approval to the consolidation of the State Bank of Suffolk, Bay Shore, L.I., into the Franklin National Bank of Franklin Square, L.I., largest bank in Nassau County.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Sixty-one educators reviewed today the role parents should play in the public schools.
Scripto, Inc., one of the largest domestic manufacturers of writing instruments, will soon invade the markets of Japan and the Far East.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 11-- Dr. Sidney E. Smith, president of the University of Toronto, has accepted the invitation of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker to become Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 11--Gov. Robert B. Meyner accused the Republican majority in the New Jersey Senate tonight of "shuffling its papers and twiddling its thumbs" while the water problem in this state was becoming more acute.
The Board of Education has quietly dropped Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" from the approved textbook lists for the city's elementary and junior high schools.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 11 --The most striking exhibit at the flower show opening today at the Northport Veterans Hospital is a double-decked fountain of California redwood flower boxes supporting sheet copper basins.

Adios Harry is as temperamental and as hard-working a standardbred horse as any racing. He will go postward for the 106th time Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway seeking his fifty-seventh victory and more money to add to his record earnings.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 11 --City officials here decided today to seek a Federal injunction against "twenty to twentyfive agitators" who are trying to block public school integration here.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 11--The application of the Birchwood community to be annexed to this village was officially received tonight by the Board of Trustees.
Nine persons, including two 14-year-old boys, were charged early today with turning a lower East Side park into a market place for narcotics.
MADRID, Sept. 11 (AP)--The jet age of air travel is dawning but, it was declared today, the navigational aids, traffic control and airports of the world are not ready for it.

ONE of the oldest taverns in this country will be reopened to the public the end of this month in Newport, R.I. It is the White Horse, which served its first meal in 1730. Jonathan Nichols was the original host.

LAST night the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House turned temporarily from the full-evening ballet to its first program of short works. All three of the ballets presented had some element of novelty about them.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11-- The Rev. Edward M. Dwyer, chairman of the department of philosophy and former dean of Villanova University, died yesterday. He suffered a heart attack in his room in the Villanova monastery. His age was 51.
LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 11 (UP) --Johnny Lattner retired from professional football today, the victim of a knee injury suffered in service football.

Stockholders at a special meeting of Namm-Loeser's, Inc., were told yesterday that the department store concern was negotiating with five different companies interested in buying it or merging with it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UP)--The National Safety Council tonight cited fifteen United States and Canadian railroads for outstanding public safety programs directed to employes and the general public.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell and President George Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.--two men who know what they are talking about in the field of labor-- strongly urge young people not to drop out of high school in order to make their summer jobs permanent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Secretary of State Dulles will go before the United Nations next week to deliver the United States' opening statement on major policy issues confronting the regular session.
The radio and television networks had nothing to say yesterday about the newly announced Papal encyclical calling for supervision of broadcast material.
The management-backed proposals for the recapitalization of Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., were approved overwhelmingly by stockholders at a fiveand-a-half-hour meeting late Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11-- Benjamin F. Fairless said here today that "while candidates for sainthood are not in generous supply in the business community, the proportion of rascals is no greater than that found among other groups of people."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Tremors from the forthcoming underground atomic explosion in Nevada may be detected as far away as Tokyo, Government scientists said today.
A possibility of protection against allergies such as hay fever was reported yesterday at the 132d national meeting of the American Chemical Society.
MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Sept. 11 (AP)--A Protestant minister joined a Roman Catholic priest today in saving altar furnishings from the tabernacle of a burning Catholic church.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The second-place St. Louis Cardinals surged to within four and a half games of the first-place Milwaukee Braves tonight by erupting early for two six-run innings and defeating the Phillies, 14--6.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 11 (Reuters)--Governor Sir John Harding announced today further relaxation of anti-terrorist laws.
OZARK, Ark., Sept. 11 (AP)-- The father of two Negro high school students said tonight an attempt had been made to kill the students.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 11 --There is an evident desire in Syria today to patch up relations with the West now that the country has Soviet arms and a promise of economic aid.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 11--Things started to tighten today as the racing entered the second half of the eight-race series for the Mallory Trophy and the North American sailing championship.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP)-- They dried the baseball field at Memorial Stadium today with a helicopter.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP)--A Soviet TU-104A jet airliner carrying members of the Russian United Nations delegation will leave here for the United States at 6 A.M. Saturday (10 P.M. Eastern Daylight time Friday).

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries realized a 3.9 per cent increase in earnings for the nine months ended July 31 on a sales gain of 3.8 per cent compared with figures for the like period a year earlier.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday sizable gains in sales, earnings and orders on hand for the first half of the year.
Man is reluctant to associate himself with an animal society. Yet he belongs to the highest order of mammalian life, a fact of major significance to the scientific world.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Sept. 11-- President Habib Bourguiba said tonight that Tunisia must have arms, "no matter what the price."

Following is the text of the first campaign address by Robert K. Christenberry, the Republican candidate for Mayor, at a meeting of the Front Office Managers Association at the Ambassador Hotel last night.
FLINT, Mich., Sept. 11--In a bid to regain third place in the automotive industry the Buick division of General Motors has invested more than $100,000,000 in its 1958 models, an official said today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11--Wladyslaw Gomulka, a man of simple tastes and frugal habits, submitted today to President Tito's appetite for princely living.
The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists yesterday picketed a Bronx plastics concern where striking employes were barred from picketing by a court injunction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --Paul M. Butler cited the high cost of living today as a major party issue. He said it was a "direct result of the mistaken economic policies and fiscal mismanagement of the Republican Administration."

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 11 --State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Republican candidate for Governor, today ended his month-long Operation Doorbell campaign by taking a ferryboat ride across the Hudson River with 300 New Jersey commuters.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11-- Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas asked President Eisenhower today to confer with him on racial integration of Central High School in Little Rock.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP)-- Vince Martinez opened a deep gash near Larry Baker's right eye and scored a nine-round technical knockout tonight when Baker was not allowed to go out for the ninth.

An excursion boat filled with sight-seers was shipwrecked briefly off Manhattan Island yesterday afternoon. Their Hudson Day Line ship swerved into a moored freight-car barge to avoid a tug-towed barge.
The Greco Management Company has purchased the seven story loft building at 110 Wes Forty-seventh Street. The build
The Yankees continued to edge sideways toward the American League pennant yesterday. By splitting a day-night twoadmission program with the Indians, the Bombers lost a half-game to the White Sox.
Stock prices rose yesterday for the first time in six days. When the final tallies were struck they showed recoveries ranging to 2 points.
Some housewives and husbands may raise their eyebrows at a statement yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America.

A 19-year-old boy in a stolen car led the police on a threemile chase through Queens yesterday. The pursuit ended when the stolen car, speeding around a corner, struck three girls on their way to school at Springfield Boulevard and Eightyninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --George Meany said today that if the ouster of some unions was necessary to clear corruption from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, then favored their expulsion.

There can be no doubt that the immigration bill signed by the President into law yesterday will relieve some severe hardships, bring hope and joy into the lives of a few score thousand people, and redound both to the immediate and to the longterm interests of the United States.
State Supreme Court Justice David W. Peck announced last night that he would retire when his term ended Dec. 31.

Detective Cammie Harding of the Thirty-second Precinct has until tomorrow to find the owner of a $1,000 violin for which one pawnbroker refused to give even $5.
LONDON, Sept. 11--A hitherto unrecognized painting by Albrecht Duerer, the early sixteenth century German artist, has been found in the collection of Sir Edmund Bacon, Premier Baronet of England.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 11 (UP) --Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands today urged ad men from all over the world to stress wise buying.
PARIS, Sept. 11--The Government said tonight that it had reached virtual agreement on its long-heralded plan to reorganize strife-torn Algeria.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 11--President Sukarno and former Vice President Mohammed Hatta, estranged leaders of the Indonesian revolution, conferred today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 11 --Parliament dissolved itself shortly before midnight tonight in a welter of confusion after having voted in favor of new elections Oct. 27.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 11 (Reuters)--Premier Pibul Songgram, ruler of Thailand for ten years, faced a major crisis today after many military leaders had left his governing party.
Governors of fifteen states and members of both houses of Congress yesterday hailed the sixtieth anniversary of the Zionist Organization of America and the world Zionist movement.
LUDLOW, N.B., Sept. 11-- Salmon and their young grilse relatives, it says somewhere, do not like to strike flies when the water is clear and the sun bright. Seasoned anglers say it, too.

So far as we are aware, no one has assumed that the Arthur Page plan for tying together a transHudson loop with New York City's subway system and New Jersey's commuter railroads was the last word in solving one phase of our community transportation problem.
Telephone workers in eight states struck briefly yesterday in a "preview" of a national walk-out set for 6 A.M. Monday.

FLORENCE, N.J., Sept. 11 --Charles T. Hunt, founder, supervisor and former owner of the Hunt Brothers Circus, died today of a heart attach at his home here in the circus' winter quarters. He was 84 years old.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) --The Canadian Massey-HarrisFerguson Company announced here tonight that it had decided not to proceed with a recent bid to take over the British Standard Motor Company.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission is considering a gradual termination of its contract with the Buffalo plant of ACF Industries, Inc. It is believed that this action would be an economy move.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11--The Soviet Union requested today an early meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission to take up the continuing East-West arms stalemate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Pentagon has canceled at least one and probably two of the six Army missile commands that were to be formed before next June 30.

An order approving the plan of reorganization of the bankrupt Northeastern Steel Corporation of Bridgeport, Conn., was signed in New Haven yesterday by Judge Robert P. Anderson of the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut.
A drop in the retail price of coffee ranging from 2 to 6 cents a pound was announced yesterday by leading roasters and supermarket chains.
Robert Moses called yesterday for more public and quasipublic housing in Harlem. He said three times as much "cancerous" slum remained there as had been eliminated by all redevelopment up to now.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 11 --The State Attorney General urged the Federal District Court today to hold off any order for immediate school integration.
Cocoa prices climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts early yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange but declined in the last half hour of trading to end down for the day.

A one-hour program comprising a study of evangelism in America will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System some time in November.

ALL the stars were in their proper places and in an especially benign mood when "Carousel" was born twelve years ago. Thank the City Center for calling it to mind periodically--in 1949, in 1954 and again last evening.
Schenley Industries, Inc., will place a heavy advertising push behind the introduction here of its Long John Scotch whisky.
LONDON, Sept. 11--Most sections of the stock market were depressed today except for British Government securities, which continued their advance.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 11--The cost of the New York section of the New England Thruway has risen 60 per cent to $96,164,000. Six months ago the cost was estimated at $60,000,000. State officials reported the new figure today to the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan Chapter of the American Public Works Association.

TORONTO, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press)--Don Fontana of Toronto, the second ranking Canadian player, was defeated today by Cliff Mayne of Berkeley, Calif., in the second round of the invitation tennis tournament, 6--3, 6--2.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 11 --Officials here are optimistic that the meeting between President Eisenhower and Gov. Orval E. Faubus will end the Little Rock public school integration dispute.

TORONTO, Sept. 11--An analysis of results from a rocket firing on Aug. 6 has provided the first direct evidence that massive sheets of electric current cap the top and bottom of the world, during magnetic storms.
A majority of directors of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Ltd., base voted to accept the purchase offer tendered by A.V. Roe (Canada), Ltd., Charles B. Lang,
EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 11-- John Flint Dille, founder and president of the National Newspaper Syndicate, died yesterday in Wesley Memorial Hospital, Chicago. He was 72 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1-- The Philadelphia Orphans Court today dismissed the petition of two Negro boys for admission to Girard College.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Government will oppose any solution to the du Pont antitrust case under which the du Pont company could continue to hold its General Motors stock permanently on a nonvoting basis.
DENVER, Sept. 11 (AP)--The national women's tennis champion, Althea, Gibson, breezed past Amy Roosevelt of Denver, 6--1, 6--0, today in secondround play in the Colorado open tennis tournament.
Lawrence M. Lyons, realty operator, has resold 119-01 to 119-13 Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, after an ownership of one day.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11--"The Diamonds of Mlle, Antoinette," a novelette by Felicen Marceau, French author, has been purchased for filming by Gene Kelly.
ALBANY, Sept. 11--Miss Carolyn Alice Herrick and Harold P. Juckett will be married in the fall.
Governor Harriman last night indicted the Eisenhower Administration's Middle East policy, declaring that for "several years the situation in the Middle East had been allowed to deteriorate."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., sept. 12--Burma proposed today that the General Assembly water down a resolution condemning Soviet suppression of the Hungarian revolt.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 (AP)--The Chilean Government announced today the closing of some copper mines because of the sharp decline in world copper prices.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 12 (UP) --Dave Beck pleaded not guilty today to seven charges involving income tax evasion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Ap) --Twenty-two colleges, universities and hospitals filed applications in August with the Community Facilities Administration for college housing loans totaling $23,423,000.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 12--Howard Talbot Walden, a customs lawyer for many years in New York, died last night at his home on Brevoort Lane here He was 98 years old.
The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission predicted yesterday that wired toll television systems, if successfully established, would be placed eventually under governmental regulation.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 6 points up yesterday. (One point equals onehundredth of a cent a pound.) The stock market seemed to continue its dull trading of yesterday.

Walter Hammitt, senior vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn and a prominent retailer for more than fifty-five years, died yesterday at his home, 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. His age was 83.
BASTROP, La., Sept. 12 (UP) --A B-47 Stratojet crashed here today. Three airmen were killed despite the pilot's order for them to bail out.

FOR its opening exhibition of the new art season, the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at Ninety-second Street, has put on a perceptive selection of paintings and drawings by Anna Walinska illustrating that artist's progress over a period of twenty-five years.

LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 12-- Former Gov. Sidney S. McMath of Arkansas disclosed today that he had directed locally a "pressure campaign" in behalf of liberals of repute, opposing Gov. Orval E. Faubus' action in the school integration impasse.
The experiences of two women as Allied espionage agents are the subjects of two books scheduled for publication this month. Next Friday, Norton will issue "The White Mouse," by Russell Braddon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) --Errors by Herb Plews and Neil Chrisley paved the way for six unearned runs that enabled the Detroit Tigers to defeat the Washington Senators, 8--5, tonight.
Mrs. George L. Weissman of New York and William Barclay Harding of Holmdel, N.J., and New York, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Harding, to Blair Chotzinoff.

Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Copper, zinc, rubber, hides and wool rose; cocoa and potatoes declined, and price movements for coffee, sugar and cottonseed oil were mixed. Volume was light in most markets.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 12--Although beaten by one second in a race won by Harry Melges of Lake Geneva, Wis., George O'Day or Marblehead moved closer to the North American senior sailing crown today.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 12 --Syria's Assistant Chief of Staff accused the United States today of trying to organize aggression against Syria.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Polish diplomats here have informally notified the State Department of their Government's desire to open negotiations on a new aid agreement.
The advertising account of the A.S.R. Products Corporation, manufacturers of razors and blades, will be awarded to Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) --Former President Truman said today that Government policy "is to abolish" the military Reserve forces. He enlisted in a campaign to "prevent" it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Louis Mitchell, an early figure in the field of jazz, died here today of a heart ailment. He was 71 years old.

THE judges huddled for three hours, checking and rechecking their arith metic in order to arrive at the winner of the Olympic figure skating championship at Cortina D'Ampezzo in February, 1956. It had to be a tight squeeze and there could be no margin for error.

Robert Cushman Murphy, ornithologist and author, testified yesterday that he believed some of the city's food supply had been poisoned by the massive DDT spraying program against the gypsy moth last spring.
The radiation of light from the sun appears to have dropped almost 1 per cent for several weeks last winter.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 12 --It is the sworn duty of the President of the United States to enforce Federal laws if the Governor of a state cannot, former President Harry S. Truman said here this afternoon.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, which include the Gertz units in New York, attained record sales in the three, six and twelve months ended July 31. Earnings, however, were lower in the quarter and half-year periods than a year ago.

Mme. Margaret Eichenwald, a leading lyric-coloratura soprano in Moscow before World War I and a teacher of singing here for nearly thirty years, died Wednesday in the Ansonia Hotel. She was 94 years old.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Sept. 12--Commuters, farmers and housewives of the metropolitan region shared honors today at the opening of the thirtyfourth annual old-fashioned country fair of the Yorktown Grange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations called on President Eisenhower today to take "firm and decisive action" on school integration in Arkansas.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union has ruled that towns and institutions should not be named for living political figures, Tass, Soviet news agency, disclosed today.

TRENTON, Sept. 12--Gov. Robert B. Meyner has retained an authority on insurance to review the testimony taken recently by the State Law Enforcement Council in its study of the mishandling of Loyalty Insurance Group funds.

Of all the characters in Mark Twain's works there probably wasn't any of whom he was fonder than the one that went down the river with Huck Finn. It is true that this character is introduced as "Miss Watson's big nigger, named Jim." That was the Missouri vernacular of that day.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept.12 --Allen R. Memhard, a retired New York corporation lawyer, died yesterday of cancer in the Greenwich Hospital after a long illness. His age was 73. He lived at 18 Crescent Road, Riverside.
The New York City Opera will open its five-week season at the City Center Oct. 9 with a revival of Puccini's "Turandot."
The State Health Department said yesterday it was standing by its recommendation of last month that everyone be inoculated with Asian influenza vactine as soon as it becomes available.

TORONTO, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press)--Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., unseeded in the Toronto invitation tennis tournament, today defeated thirdseeded Luis Ayala of Chile,1--6, 7--5, 6--4. Ayala is ranked tenth in the world.
Frederic Wakeman, author of such novels as "Shore Leave," "The Hucksters" and "The Saxon Charm," has written an original play called "The LongWinged Bird."
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 12-- Tony Curtis and his wife, Janet Leigh, will be co-starred by Universal-International in "The Perfect Furlough," a comedy based on a screenplay by Stanley Shapiro.

REHOVOT, Israel, Sept. 12-- Experiments suggesting the existence of two of the strangest particles in nature were described here today at the International Conference on Nuclear Structure at the Weizmann Institute of Science.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) --Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto today signed a new one-year contract to manage the Washington Senators and said he would trade anyone except Roy Sievers to lift his team from the American League cellar.

"THE DEATH OF MANOLETE," a dramatiza tion of the career of the Spanish bullfighter, with Jack Palance in the title role, was presented last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. The work contained the ingredients for a moving tragedy but it fell noticeably short of its goal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The International Monetary Fund announced today a loan of $68,750,000 to The Netherlands. At the same time The Netherlands arranged a stand by credit of the same amount to be available for drawing any time in the next year.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12--The conference between Gov. Orval E. Faubus and President Eisenhower on the school integration crisis here was arranged by an Arkansas Congressman.
United States rayon and acetate producers shipped 94,000,000 pounds of fiber in August, 5 per cent above the July level and 5 per cent more than in August, 1956.
LONDON, Sept. 12--The British Government has proposed the abolition of all travel restrictions on Soviet officials in Britain and members of the British Embassy in Moscow.

The appeal yesterday by Israel's Ambassador to Washington that this country make "crystal clear" its op position to "any aggression against the integrity or independence of Middle East states, including Israel," should be answered directly and affirmatively.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 12--United Nations observers have quietly knocked down the persistently recurring scare story of a vast United States military build-up in the Himalayas.
Women will be eliminated from advertisements for tourism and rum placed by the Puerto Rican Economic Development Administration.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and the Yanhee Electricity Authority of Thailand yesterday signed an agreement for a loan of $66,000,000. It will help finance a vast project for the development of electric power, flood control and irrigation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- King Saud of Saudi Arabia has sent a message to President Eisenhower urging moderation in United States policy toward Syria, diplomatic sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The State Department accused the Soviet Foreign Minister today of slipping back into Stalinism.

Sales of seventy-three companies in the pulp and paper field during the first half of 1957 were 8 per cent higher than in the same period last year, but earnings declined 11.6 per cent, the American Paper and Pulp Association reported yesterday.

Mayor Wagner appealed last night for his re-election "by a tremendous margin that will resound from coast to coast." Such a victory, he said, would portend new Democratic triumphs next year and in 1960.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The Department of Defense has refused to tell a Congressional subcommittee why it applied security clearance procedures to a review of a book by a Civil War general.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 12--The fifty-second Piping Rock Horse Show opened a four-day program this afternoon at the Piping Rock Club. More than 1,200 entries will be exhibited from many parts of the East and South.

Roy Foster, realty investor, has purchased the four-story store and apartment building at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street. The property is 18.9 by 68 feet and is assessed at $75,000. It was bought in a deal negotiated by Huberth Huberth, brokers.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc. established record sales in the six and twelve-month periods ended July 31. The store chain also increased its earnings over the corresponding periods of the preceding year, according to the semi-annual report of Bruce A Gimbel, president.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 12 --This is the year of the big revival (meaning the Notre Dame game) and the Army football squad is working intensively under Earl (Red) Blaik to be ready for the Fighting Irish.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12-- Trapper Tut swerved to the outside at the top of the stretch, then went on to win the Stewart Manor Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Five trading concerns sought court assistance yesterday in an effort to recover valuable import cargoes that have been tied up on ships in the harbor here for nearly four weeks.
The seventy-one New York State mutual savings banks that own Institutional Investors Mutual Funds, Inc., approved yesterday a ten-for-one split in the shares of the fund.

Devotees of some sports seem to prefer being hermits. But not pleasure boatmen. For instance, the trout fisherman stakes out his pet, cool, gurgling pool and then wants to fish it without the company of spectators. He is a "loner."
BONN, Germany, Sept. 12-- Otto Strasser, a power in the Nazi party thirty years ago, has tacitly conceded defeat in his attempt to rebuild a personal Fascist political movement in West Germany.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey asserted tonight that Government policy had been "far too shortsighted" in understanding the power that food and fiber played in international relations.
UNLESS you can resist the temptation to replace your entire wardrobe, stay away from Ohrbach's.
Clendenin James Ryan, who used his large fortune in often turbulent political crusades against crime and corruption, ended his life with a bullet yesterday, He was 52 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The United States Government announced today that, with a few exceptions, aid to foreign countries would henceforth not be provided to finance stateowned industry and mining.
BONWIT TELLER has just pulled off an eye-popping fashion coup in Europe that may start a new trend in American stores.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 12--Charles F. Coates, former chairman of the Connecticut Development Commission and a leading accountant, was found dead in his wrecked car today in New Milford, Conn. He was 67 years old.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12-- King Hussein of Jordan returned to Amman, his capital, tonight from a three-week rest cure in Turkey and Spain to face a new political crisis.

Loans to business by the large New York City banks rose $105,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the like week last year, they were up $108,000,000.

About New York THE city's two articulate mail boxes have been chat ting with passers-by in front of the General Post Office and at Grand Central Station for sixteen months now, but have yet to win anything like the acceptance that other talking holes--the radio, the telephone and the television-- enjoy.
Member banks operated under easier reserve pressures in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
A self-unloading super collier, twice as big as conventional coal-carrying ships in use along the Atlantic Coast, has been ordered by the Pocahontas Steamship Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--One of the curious effects of the public violence over moves toward school racial desegregation in parts of the South and the Federal-state conflicts of authority in others are the implications left by some comment on the international consequences of these events.
IN 1944 while the world waited tensely for the opening of the second front many thousands of men were fighting and dying in Italy on what Sir Winston Churchill aptly called the third front.
The city's efforts to keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn are expected to be discussed when the Board of Estimate meets in an executive session at 11 A.M. today.
Any combination of eleven Yankee victories and White Sox defeats will assure the world champion Bombers of their twenty-third American League pennant.
The Board of Education yesterday invited all interested persons and groups to suggest candidates for the post of Superintendent of Schools.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 12 --The inequality of the sexes in the professions was deplored again today as 700 business and professional women gathered here for a three-day conference.

Miss Diane M. Douglas of 333 East Fifty-third Street was married yesterday afternoon at the River Club to Anthony Drexel Duke of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Pompano Beach, Fla. The Rev. Walter Donald Kring of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony in the presence of the families.
Nuclear Metals, Inc., Cambridge, Mass., announced yesterday completion of its transition from a Government-owned atomic energy research facility to complete private ownership and operation.
PARIS, Sept. 12--Two political leaders, regarded as experts on Africa, attacked the proposed constitutional law for Algeria, today on opposite grounds.

A new issue of $40,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Philadelphia Electric Company is being offered for public subscription today, yielding investors 4.625 per cent to maturity in 1987.
The Union of South Africa yesterday registered $15,000,000 of ten year external loan bonds, due Oct. 1, 1967, with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Baltimore County, Md., borrowed $23,550,000 on bond issues yesterday to finance various public improvements. The borrowing brought an interest cost of 3.9018 per cent.

Robert J. Kleberg, the boss of the million-acre King Ranch, was among the 17,810 visitors to Belmont Park yesterday. He had an extra-pleasant afternoon. He saw King Ranchers win the sixth and seventh races.

A motorist pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of using a telephone in his car while the vehicle was in motion. To the best recollection of personnel attached to Manhattan Traffic Court and Vehicle Accident Court, it was the first summons of its kind issued here.
The United Textile Workers of America suspended the officers of Local 229 yesterday and placed a trustee over the New York unit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- An Administration spokesman and one of its severest critics emphasized separately today then Soviet Union's growing military power.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The Treasury anonunced today plans for borrowing $3,000,000,000. The offering will include its first long-term bond issue in more than two years, and two shorter issues, all at a 4 per cent interest rate.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Sept. 12-- President Habib Bourguiba assured Tunisia tonight that she "will get arms."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 12 (Reuters)--The Johannesburg City Council has been ordered by the local transport board to apply total segregation to all municipal transport services within two weeks.
WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 12--Tuna teams of seven nations went out in twentyone boats today in the second round of the International Tuna Match and briskly caught no fish.

Dr. Gabrielle Lauber Newman of 320 East Forty-second Street, a retired educator, died Wednesday in University Hospital after an illness of four months. Her age was 71.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) --A $3,000,000 loan to Columbia University was announced by the Community Facilities Administration today. The money will finance the construction of a dormitory for 605 men students.

ECONOMY-MINDED shoppers will probably by pass beer again this week-end for more attractively priced meats. Except for a few special features, beef prices have maintained current levels that remove this popular fare from the reach of most budgets.
How can a museum in New York in 1957 A.D. legitimately dispose of the body of a man born in Egypt about 235 A.D.?
A Harvard cancer researcher said yesterday that transplanted tumors were excellent tools for the study of cancer cells, but that cures must be verified on natural tumors.

NEWARK, Sept. 12--A professor of economics at the University of Wisconsin appeared today before the Public Utilities Commission to bolster the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company's application for a $14,148,000 increase in intrastate rates.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (UP)--Jim Wilson kept the Chicago White Sox' slim pennant hopes alive as he became the first American League pitcher to beat the Red Sox five times this season with a 7-1 triumph at Fenway Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) --Meade Alcorn, Republican national chairman, asserted today that the Democrats' l958 campaign would be based on the "phony issue" that the American standard of living was declining.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission today ordered hearings to begin here Oct. 1 on questions involved in the New York State Power Authority's proposed Niagara Falls hydro-electric project.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 12 (AP)--Dorothy Counts, one of four Negro children admitted to Charlotte schools last week, is withdrawing from Harding High School.

Stockholders of Loew's, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday that lasted about four minutes, were informed that Joseph R. Vogel, president, had received the backing of a majority of the outstanding stock in his fight for control of the motionpicture company.

TORONTO, Sept. 12--In an emotion-tinged ceremony, the first two aliens to be accepted under the new "hardship" terms of the Immigration Act were welcomed today by Livingston Merchant, United States Ambassador.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 12 --Gen. Phao Sriyanond resigned today as Minister of Interior and Secretary General of the Government party. Premier Pibul Songgram indicated the resignation would be accepted.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The homebuilding industry has just received its best statistical news in months.

This newspaper's correspondent Harrison E. Salisbury completes in these pages today a series of articles giving the first first-hand report on Albania that any American correspondent has been able to make in a decade.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 12--Jessica Newberry of the Sleepy Hollow Riding Club gained her second straight leg on the new Merrill-Robertson Challenge Trophy by taking the Special Dressage Class as the fifty-second Piping Rock horse show opened today.
PULA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 --Wladyslaw Gomulka of Poland was initiated today into the workings of Yugoslav communism, with President Tito as his guide.
The stock market extended yesterday the recovery that developed Wednesday afternoon. Prices as measured by the averages scored their best gains of the year.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 12 --A sweep by American Walker Cup players of the four semifinal places in the United States amateur golf championship was assured tonight when Rex Baxter, the intercollegiate titleholder, won a twenty-one-hole match.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday awarded two contracts totaling $4,568,625 for major work on Piers 1 and 2 of its $85,000,000 waterfront development program in Brooklyn.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12-- President Eisenhower and Gov. Orval F. Fanbus of Arkansas arranged today to confer at 9 o'clock Saturday morning on Little Rock school integration problems.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 12-- The Bedford Golf and Tennis Club was the setting this evening for the debuts of the Misses Patricia Stuart Bijur, Judith Hill and Barbara Jacobi.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12--Representative Brooks Hays is a lay church leader dedicated to the idea that a synthesis of moral imperatives and social-economic factors can provide the solution to the South's race relations problem.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12-- After tonight's bizarre contest at County Stadium the Braves ought to be rated as destiny's darlings. The manner in which they beat the Dodgers, 2--1, and increased their league lead to five games will rankle in the Brooks' breasts for months to come.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12--A cheering throng of more than one thousand Negroes presented a plaque to Senator William F. Knowland today in appreciation of his recent Congressional work in behalf of civil rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A "very persuasive" letter from President Eisenhower helped to influence Sir Winston Churchill to permit a touring exhibit of his paintings next year in the United States and Canada.
ROME, Sept. 12--Italian oil interests will move into Iran immediately and start work on developing concessions they have been granted.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12-- Gov. Robert B. Meyner toured Hudson County today. The Governors stops included City Hall here, where he sought to conciliate two Democratic factions.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 12 --The Chief Army Engineer in New England told a group of regional industrialists today that their plants were "pitifully unprotected" against floods.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 12--The Federal District Court issued an order today to halt threats and violence aimed against the integration of Nashville's schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The United States rejected today a Communist Chinese proposal for a reciprocal exchange of news correspondents.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 12--Further shortening of the work-week will bring to the average American more real leisure than all such gains in the last generation, a conference of planners and zoners heard today.
The Spiral Group, composed of sixteen painters and sculptors, is holding its twelfth annual exhibition at the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- John S. Graham, an official in the Truman Administration and a fund-raiser for the Democratic party, was sworn in today as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12--French and Togolese representatives assured the Trusteeship Council today that the transfer of powers and responsibilities to Togoland was continuing satisfactorily and that more gains could be expected.

LONDON, Sept. 12--Fresh liquidation turned early gains among industrial shares into net losses in the stock market today. Oils rallied again in late dealings, but with Government issues quieter it was left to the South African gold minings to make the best showing of the day.

TOKYO, Sept. 4--Japanese physicians have isolated what they believe to be the best strain of Asian influenza virus.
BONN, Germany, Monday, Sept. 16--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer won yesterday's general election in West Germany by a landslide.

Whatever the outcome of Sugar Ray Robinson's boxing bout with Carmen Basilio next Monday, the current middleweight titleholder will still be king on Oct. 17. On that date Mr. Robinson will portray the King of Babylon in a television version of "The Green Pastures."
LONDON, Sept. 15--The London stock markets finished last week on a cheerful note on the improvement in Wall Street prices.
FEW baseball managers had more big league jobs than Bucky Harris and none ever was better qualified to discourse on the subject than he.
PARIS, Sept. 15--The Atlantic alliance, which is starting the largest series of maneuvers in its history, is about to open a critical year.

HARTFORD, Sept. 15--A half-hour television program opened Civil Defense Week here today. The program, showing what might happen if Connecticut came under enemy attack, was realistic enough to scare some people into believing that the county was actually being invaded.
Mayor Wagner has notified the City Planning Commission that expenditures within the debt limit for capital improvements in 1958 must not exceed $444,100,000.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15-- The American Legion convention committee on rehabilitation today voted unanimously, 58-0, to reject proposals for general pensions for war veterans.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 15--Joseph J. Garibaldi, a wellknown New Jersey realty executive, died today at the Orange Memorial Hospital. His age was 67.
THE LITTLE BOOK SHOP at 25 Hanson Place in Brooklyn is a block from the junction of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues. It is run for the love of books by an unpretentious intellectual in shirt sleeves.
Chief Justice Earl Warren called yesterday for a new kind of effort to discover the common denominator of faith and understanding among the religions and peoples of the world.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Steelers, in a trade with the San Francisco Forty-Niners, today acquired Earl Morrall, a National Football League second-year man who was a star at Michigan State.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday granted a motion to give defense counsel a list of the names and addresses of witnesses scheduled to testify against Col. Rudolf Ivanovich
Net income of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries topped $42,000,000 for the first time in the fiftytwo weeks ended Aug. 31, the company reported yesterday.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16-- President Eisenhower today appointed Rocco C. Siciliano of Chicago as Special Assistant for Personnel Management. This is a new White House post.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 16--Federal District Court Judge William E. Miller after a four-hour hearing today granted an injunction against agitators who had been fighting desegregation of this city's schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16-The General Assembly will open its twelfth annual session here tomorrow with the agenda loaded with old and new international issues that point to a number of floor fights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The official spokesman for the International Cooperation Administration said today that the agency's directive curbing loans to state-owned industries abroad "remains in effect, and will make a definite difference in our actual operations." The directive has aroused much controversy.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 16--The full picture of the political ramifications stirred by the Little RocK school-integration controversy was coming into sharper focus today.
New York State will market the first in a series of mental health construction bonds Oct. 1, Controller Arthur Levitt announced yesterday. The first offering will be $24,000,000.

Blueprints are being outlined for two outstanding teams of entrepreneurs to pool their resources in getting "Skyscraper" to the stage. The musical is to be produced next season by Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin. They have approached Oscar Hammerstein 2d to create the book and lyrics and Richard Rodgers the melodies.

LONDON, Sept. 16--Viscount Hailsham was named Lord President of the Council by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tonight. His appointment as chairman of the Conservative party organization is expected soon.

CAIRO, Sept. 16--President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have offered to send Syria Egyptian jet pilots and military technicians to help train the Syrian Army in the use of new Soviet bloc weapons.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 16 --How a dying community was brought back to life through the efforts of a religious organization was told today at the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.
Business and labor leaders are cooperating in a pilot project to find work for idle youths in the East Bronx.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 16--As fine a sailing day as the summer has produced also produced a victory for the Long Island Sound team against Bermuda in the first race for the Amorita Cup today.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP)--Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said today that "some of the super-confidence must be shaken out of the boom" to help stabilize the economy.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Smashing out of their batting slump, the Milwaukee Braves tonight collected fourteen hits, including a home run by Del Rice, as they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5--1, and stretched their National League lead to three games.
Since sparsely clad Redskins paddled their canoes up and down the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers and their tributaries, innumerable men have dreamed of reclaiming the Jersey meadows.
A 14-year-old girl walked out of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn yesterday twenty days after an operation that closed a hole in her heart.
TORONTO, Sept. 11--A few days ago a Soviet scientist offered to lend to an American scientist unpublished, detailed maps of earthquake activity throughout the Soviet Union.
The New York Philharmonic has announced, for the first time in its history, the complete set of its programs for the coming season.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Sept. 17--The Army seized control of the Government of Premier Pibul Songgram in a bloodless coup early today.
Telephone equipment installers went on strike at 6 A.M. yesterday in forty-four states and the District of Columbia. TELEPHONE UNION BEGINS WALKOUT
Charles J. Liebman, a business man and art collector who devoted much of his life to easing the plight of refugees, died Sunday afternoon at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old.
Open warfare broke out anew yesterday within the Democratic party in Hudson County, N.J., and posed a serious threat to the re-election chances of Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., yesterday called attention to its recent sixtieth anniversary by reporting on its far-flung 1956-57 activities.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16--Wladyslaw Gomulka of Poland and President Tito of Yugoslavia agreed today on a joint platform of support for Soviet foreign policy and of reconcilation with neighboring Communist countries.
Monday is shaping up as a "who-cares" day in Wall Street. Stocks drifted down yesterday in the second lightest volume of the year. It was the eighth consecutive Monday that prices declined.
Six hundred luxury apartments and hotel suites in this city were stripped of rent controls, effective next March 15, in an order yesterday by the State Rent Administrator.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)--Federal and state agencies began a joint investigation tonight into last night's crash of a twin-engined Northeast Airlines DC-3. Eleven persons died in the crash and thirteen others were injured.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 16 --Ultra-colonialist forces made plans today for an Algeria-wide general strike Wednesday in protest against the reforms to be voted in Paris for this rebellion-torn land.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 16 (UP)-- nuclear device borne by a balloon 1,500 feet above the ground was exploded early today. The blast was seen 350 miles away and motorists were ordered off the road to avoid possible eye burns.

As the public schools open with more or less "deliberate speed" a11 over the United States, another sort of school will have its first session this morning under a domed roof beside the East River. This school, which whatever its deficiencies is at least completely integrated, is the Twelfth Session of the United Nations General Assembly.

Ghanshyamdas D. Birla, one of India's most prominent industrialists, warned yesterday that unless his country obtained a $500,000,000 loan from the United States her second FiveYear Plan faced failure.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- Dr. Fred L. Soper, director of the Pan American Sanitary Bureau, said today that Asian influenza spread faster than teams of experts could be sent in to record its sweep.

TEVYA, the dairyman, is a wise and lovable man who enjoys a remarkably personal relationship to God. But to judge by Arnold Perls' "Tevya and His Daughters," acted at Carnegie Hall Playhouse last evening, Tevya still needs to be enclosed in a play.

LONDON, Sept. 16--Gerald Matthews Balding, former international championship polo player and trainer for many years of the stable in England of John Hay Whitney, United States Ambassador to Britain, died here today of cancer. He was 54 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) --The Federal Maritime Board was asked today to disregard future ship replacement costs in considering freight rates on ocean cargo.
As many as 50,000 voters may have been assigned to the wrong polling places during central registration, the president of the Board of Elections estimated yesterday.
The kind of military takeover that occurred in Thailand yesterday is not a unique phenomenon in the political life of that country.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16--The Redlegs defeated the Dodgers, 3--2, in the tenth inning tonight when Eddie Roebuck walked Joe Taylor with the bases filled.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16-- The annual all-day parade of the American Legion was held under warm, sunny skies today as a prelude to the opening of its thirty-ninth national convention tomorrow.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 16--National Guardsmen remained on duty today in front of the all-white Central High School.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 16 --Giorgio Morandi of Italy, 67year-old recluse painter of Bologna, today won the "Sao Paulo Prize" for plastic arts, one of the world's most coveted awards in modern art. The prize carries 300,000 oruzeiros (about $3,850).

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16--Allied Artists plans to release thirty-six pictures during the next twelve months. This will be an increase of six over the production season just ended for the company and, in fact, will be its heaviest undertaking in five years, according to Steve Broidy, president.
Thirty thousand commuters had to seek other means of transportation home last night when a failure of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad's signal system put 180 trains out of service.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 16 --The trial of a damage suit brought against the Beech Aircraft Corporation by the estate of a pilot killed flying a Beech plane opened here today.
The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad signed a new wage agreement yesterday with the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
Relatives and friends of Vincent L. Gigante, the 29-year-old hoodlum accused of attempting to murder Frank Costello, posted a $100,000 bond yesterday for the defendant's release on bail.

In an election which broke a11 precedents of German parliamentary history the people of West Germany have rolled up a landslide victory for Chancellor Adenauer arid therewith cast a large majority of their votes for the West, for European unification and for a collective defense of Western civilization against Communist aggression. Jewel's Reward of the Maine Chance Farm added $24,925 to his ample bankroll by winning the Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The son of Jet Jewel won the thirty-fifth running of the Cowdin with a steady performance under the guidance of Willie Hartack.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 (AP)--The boards of the Hartford Electric Light Company and the Connecticut Power Company today approved the merger of the two public utility companies.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Mayor Charles P. Taft said today that his father, William Howard Taft, foreshadowed what is now called "modern Republicanism" when he was President and later as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

This country's privately owned shipyards have two and a half times the number of new ship orders that were on hand a year ago according to the monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 16--The United States trailed Israel, 40 points to 59, after the first day's events in track and field at the fifth Maccabiah, the "Jewish Olympic Games," today.
DALLAS, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Sam Snead won his ninety-sixth golf tournament today. He shot a 3-under-par 68 for 264 to triumph by 10 strokes in the $40,000 Dallas open.

Mayor, Wagner took cognizance yesterday of Republican charges that his Administration had failed to cope adequately with the city's juvenile crime problem.

Two of the city's leading real estate concerns. Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., and Hollyday Ives, Inc., have merged, it was announced yesterday. The new concern will bear the name of Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc.

SIMPLE mathematics illustrates the advantage of one of the less-used cuts of lamb, the shank. Shank, which looks a little like a miniature leg of lamb, costs 23 cents a pound now. A pair of half-pound shanks would serve two amply for 11 cents a portion.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 16-A pair of home-club players, Mickey Homa and Clyde S. Rine, scored a 2-stroke victory as seventyeight teams participated in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur competition at the Westchester C. C. today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16--The statements made by the President and the Governor of Arkansas after their Newport conference moved back into perspective the issue of their official responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The president of the ExportImport Bank said today that the recent inter-American economic conference at Buenos Aires "was a success, news reports to the contrary notwithstanding."

LEVITTOWN, Pa., Sept. 16-- Dogwood Hollow, scene of racial strife last month over the settling of a Negro family in an all-white community, opened its new elementary school today with a Negro teaching fifth grade.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Msgr. Louis R. Stickney, pastor of the Shrine of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here, died yesterday at the church rectory. He was 78 years old.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP)-- Dr. Walter Irvin Beam, wellknown financier and one of the original directors of Florida's Inter-American Trade Center, died at his home yesterday. His age was 72.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16-- The Los Angeles City Council, by a vote of 11 to 3, adopted a resolution today to open official negotiations with the Brooklyn baseball club for the erection of a stadium in the Chavez Ravine area.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The Federal Communications Commission was asked today to consider a fourth system of pay television.
A comprehensive plan to transform 1,100 acres of the Jersey Meadows into a vast mosquito-free park and recreational area was outlined here yesterday by its authors.
LONDON, Sept. 16--Stock market price movements were small in a quiet session today. Trading rarely showed any decided trend.
DAVISVILLE, R.I., Sept. 16 --Nearly a hundred United States scientists received the first of a series of briefings today on life in Antarctica.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 16--Israel charged today that Soviet agents in Odessa had tried to force an Israeli attache to become a spy.

Office workers of the Italian Line in the Port of New York voted 61 to 44 in factor of representation by the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday.
Cocoa futures fell the 1-centa-pound daily limit in all positions during trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. A light rally toward the close raised prices from the lows of the day.

One of the first acts of William Proxmire, following his surprise election to the Senate, was to send a telegram to President Eisenhower.
CAIRO, Sept. 16 (AP)--Saudi Arabians say they could double or even triple their already fabulous oil income if they could make a new deal with the Arabian American Oil Company.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 16-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was greeted today with hero worship at home, adulation in the Western governments and cold fury by his defeated opponents and many independents.

THE natural reaction of many women after a visit to the National Home Furnishings show at the Coliseum is first, aching feet, and second, an irresistible urge to go right home and do the whole place over.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 12 points (5 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday after fluctuating in a narrow range.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16-- Argentina marked today the second anniversary of the overthrow of Juan D. Peron in an uneasy state.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 --The County Transportation System, which operates buses between Stamford, Conn., and New Rochelle, N.Y., said today it was willing to reconsider its petition for abandonment of its bus service between the two cities.

EEL BROOK, Nova Scotia, Sept. 16--Something odd in the way of fishing has turned up in Eel Lake here but nobody in the neighborhood seems to be particularly excited about it. In brief, the bottom of Eel Lake seems to be paved with tautog or blackfish.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--Industrial production failed to rise in August despite record levels of employment, personal income and retail sales. reported today that its monthly index of the output of mines, mills and factories stood at 144 per cent of the 1947-49 average.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The Government welcomed today Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's sweeping election victory as solid reinforcement of basic United States foreign policy objectives.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP)--The entire futures list declined on the Board of Trade in active dealings today.

John J. Canfield of 2473 Devoe Terrace, the Bronx, general manager of Macfadden Publications, Inc., magazine publishers of this city, died Monday night at Midtown Hospital after an illness of three weeks.

The joint Polish-Yugoslav communique issued in Belgrade on Monday covered many topics, but world public opinion will probably focus particularly on the remarks concerning relations among Communist-ruled countries.

Mayor Wagner gave general approval yesterday to the idea of a rapid transit link between New York and New Jersey but disagreed in most particulars with a plan that would accomplish it.

Belmont Park popped up yesterday with an exceptionally good stake for today's card. Eleven standout performers are scheduled to compete in the $29,350. Nassau County Handicap.

ROME, Sept. 17--Widows are quite within their rights if they remarry, but the Roman Catholic Church loves them more if they remain true to the memory of their dead husbands, Pope Pius XII said yesterday.

William A. Vecchio Jr. was operating a road-grading machine in Queens last Friday when he saw a woman's handbag drop from an automobile. He retrieved the handbag, but his attempts to signal the driver were unsuccessful.
Dr. Edward M. Nash, a psychiatrist died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived and had an office at 470 West End Avenue.
Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley was invited yesterday to install parking meters in Stuyvesant Town to end double parking in the huge East Side project.
Dr. Armand Eisler, a former Viennese lawyer who was imprisoned in Nazi concentration camps, died Monday in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, after a long illness. His age was 77.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 17 --Seymour Lipton, a 54-yearold New Yorker who uses sheet steel as his art medium, won the Acquisition Prize for Sculpture today at the Sao Paulo fourth Biennial Exhibition of Modern Arts.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 17 --Mr. and Mrs. Zenas Crane Colt have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Frances Crane Colt, to Theodore LaRue Lutkins of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore LaRue Lutkins of Towners, N.Y.

For seven innings against the Tigers yesterday, the Yankees, except for Bobby Shantz, played as if this were just another September game--something to get over and done with.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 --The San Francisco Opera Association announced today that it had taken action against the seprano Maria Meneghini Callas for her "refusal to fulfill her contract obligations."

"A Touch of the Poet," which, according to the publishers, is the last written of his full-length plays, will add nothing. PARIS, Sept.26--Robert Lacoste, Minister for Algeria, attempted to win over the French Right wing today to a bill to reform Algeria's political structure.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26-- Argentina's Provisional Government prepared tonight for a showdown with organized labor.
TRENTON, Sept. 26--State Senator James F. Murray Jr. announced here today after an hour-long talk with Gov. Robert B. Meyner that he would not seek re-election to the Senate.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices dipped to 86.1 on Wednesday, the lowest since Oct. 19, 1953. On Tuesday the index was 86.2. The figure for Sept. 26, 1956 was 91.8.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Scholarship money available to undergraduate college students has increased two and a half times in the last five years, the Office of Education reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund ended their annual meeting today by choosing New Delhi, India, as the site of next year's session.
Member bank reserve positions tightened in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
College athletic officials throughout the nation will be anxiously awaiting the results of an experiment at Boston University tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--An examiner for the Subversive Activities Control Board recommended today that the American Committed for the Protection of the Foreign Born be required to register with the Attorney General as a Communist-front organization.

State fishing licenses for all salt-water sports fishermen from Maine to Florida were proposed yesterday to the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission. Licenses are now required only of fresh-water anglers.

LEVITTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26 (AP)--William Hughes locked his vacant house by court order tonight after telling about fifty persons they no longer could use the premises as an anti-integration "social club." The house is next door to the home of this community's only Negro family.

With a net income from all sources of $9,145,983, August was the best month so far this year for the Union Pacific Railroad. In August of 1956, net income was $8,470,066.

THE Peter and Paul Fortress in St. Petersburg enjoyed a sinister reputation in the last days of the Czarist autocracy. There the most dangerous enemies of the moribund state were confined and some were never heard of again.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican minority leader of the City Council, will be 75 years old today. He will observe the anniversary with characteristic quiet. There will be a luncheon party at his law office and dinner with his family.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (UP)--The Times of London and The Manchester Guardian today praised President Eisenhower's "patience" in handling the Little Rock integration crisis, Several other papers were beginning to voice similar views.

The results of the Haitian election for President are not yet official, but it seems clear enough that Dr. Francois Duvalier is going to be declared the victor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The Army revoked today a training directive issued yesterday to prepare certain Regular Army units to deal with possible crises similar to the one at Little Rock, Ark.
TODAY is the seventyfourth birthday of Peter Merli, senior captain of the Staten Island ferryboats. Hale in body and spirit, he has no wish to retire.

Outboard boating has finally reached the V-age. This week's unveiling of the 1958 designs in portable, stern transom power plants finds both Evinrude and Johnson bringing out for the first time four-cylinder V-motors.

Two hold-up men robbed a Park Avenue jewelry store of $100,000 in gems yesterday. The robbery was carried out in eight minutes, neatly and quietly.
