WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The Air Force announced today a realignment of its reserve forces that will eliminate twelve wings and thirteen squadrons of the Air Force Reserve and the Air National Guard.
Draft indebtedness of Latin American importers to United States exporters declined last month by $6,400,000 the fourth consecutive monthly drop, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--American motorists soon will be seeing a new marker designating official route numbers on the vast network of interstate superhighways.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Sept. 26-- President Habib Bourguiba vigorously reaffirmed Tunisia's loyalty to the West today in a speech telling his people that the United States had promised to help his country get arms.

Leaving two of their wounded behind them, the Yankees entrained yesterday afternoon for Boston, where today they'll open a three-game series with the Red Sox. The set will close the regular season for the Bombers on Sunday.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- America's Ryder Cup team flew into London today, quietly confident of carrying on its long string of victories against Britain in the 30-year-old golf test.
ALTHOUGH meat prices in general are not in the budget bracket, shoppers will find a great variety of attractive meat features in the stores this week-end.

TWENTY-FIVE artists associated with Kraushaar's, 1055 Madison Avenue, are represented by one drawing each in the opening show of the new art season at the gallery. There is a wide selection of themes and techniques and the level of quality in the work is high.

Heavy trade hedge selling and commission house liquidation tumbled wool prices sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--A gigantic poker game, with billions of dollars and the reputation of the world's most widely used currency at stake, is quietly being played out in the world's financial centers.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 26-- A Canadian pacing mare, Dottie's Pick, handled by Jimmy Arthur, snapped a thirteen-race losing streak tonight.

MAEBASHI, Japan, Sept. 26 --A Japanese witness to the shooting last Jan. 30 of a Japanese woman by an American soldier testified today at the trial for manslaughter of Specialist 3/c William S. Girard.

The flow of capital from this country to foreign investments continues unabated. Naturally enough, South America would welcome more of the same. To that end, two former Colombian diplomats visited the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 26 (UP) --Bill Harrell, a rookie, hit a triple and a single and scored an unearned run tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 2-1 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics. It was the Athletics' final home game of the season.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 26 --Wes Ellis, who held the lead at the end of each round, became the metropolitan open golf champion today.
New York State school districts sold bond issues totaling $2,140,000 yesterday.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 26 --The Rev. Theodore Brinckerhoff today felt a little lilte Moses as the Red Sea moved aside to open the Land of Promise.

Joseph Holzka, executive vice president of the Northfield Savings and Loan Association, Staten Island, has been nominated for the presidency of the United States Savings and Loan League.

Sales of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., are expected to cross the $200,000,000 mark this year for the first time in the company's history, Edwin H. Smith, controller, said yesterday. He spoke at a meeting of the San Francisco Society of Security Analysts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers virtually assured themselves of a first-division berth for the first time since 1950 by defeating the White Sox, 3 to 2, today. They need only one more victory to clinch fourth place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--A twenty-year contract for Government subsidy to the Mississippi Shipping Company, operator of the Delta Freight and Passenger Line, was signed today by Clarence G. Morse, Maritime Administrator.

James R. Hoffa is now in a box. Up to a few weeks ago it seemed sure that he would satisfy his overriding ambition: to be elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters at its Miami convention next month.

Outstanding loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $108,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A subway motorman was killed yesterday morning when his empty ten-car train crashed into the rear of another empty train. The accident occurred on the elevated section of the IRT Broadway-Seventh Avenue line at 230th Street, the Bronx.

The proclamation by Mayor Wagner of October as PAL Month in New York City, in honor of the Police Athletic League, calls deserved attention of the public to the PAL drive for funds opening Oct. 1.

Robert Moses withdrew angrily yesterday from further negotiation with the Federal government over the price the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and Fordham University should pay for sites in the Lincoln Square project.
BONN, Germany Sept. 26-- The executive board of the Social Democratic party has defeated a rank-and-file movement for a wholesale reappraisal of Socialist policies and leadership.

A client of Herman Agins, who recently bought a contract of purchase on 749 East Ninth Street, at Avenue D, from Dr. L. Goldberg, has resold the contract to William Michaelman. Mr. Michaelman then resold his contract to an investor.

"The Best of Burlesque," costarring Sherry Britton and Tom Poston, opens at midnight tonight at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse. It is the first of a continuing series of Friday ands Saturday night performances.

Loans outstanding in statesupervised banks in the United States rose $4.2 billions in the year ended June 30, the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks reported yesterday. At $64,267,025,000, loans accounted for 48.7 per cent of total assets.
Robert R. Young received a sharp setback yesterday in his efforts to simplify the capital structure of the Alleghany Corporation, the holding company of which he is chairman.

Major crime in New York City increased 1.3 per cent in the first six months of 1957 and arrests of juvenile delinquents rose 13.6 per cent over the same period in 1956, the Police Department said yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27-- The route to victory was paved with gold for the Brightside Farms' Hundred Proof tonight when the rangy 5-year-old pacer took the $50,000 Transamerica final before 26,725 persons at Roosevelt Raceway.

SEATTLE, Sept. 27 (AP)--WalF. O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and other National League team owners are giving serious thought to including Seattle in a ten-team realignment of the league, a financier said today.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 18 --An American with a big-city background has found contentment as a Buddhist monk in the quiet countryside near here.

Dr. George A. Merrill of 816 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, internist and allergist, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 74. He had been director of medicine at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn for thirty-two years.

Mrs. Marie Azeez el-Khoury of 160 East Seventy-second Street, for many years one of this city's leading and most original jewelry designers, died on Thursday at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She would have observed her seventy-fifth birthday next Wednesday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP)--Vice President Chuck Comiskey of the Chicago White Sox today confirmed a report that the White Sox and the Baltimore Orioles were on the verge of a big player trade.

The religious observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the Jewish New Year 5718, ended at sundown yesterday. In sermons at temples and synagogues here, Jewish spiritual leaders called for a rededication to the principles of Judaism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture said today that the farm mortgage debt continued to rise this year, although at a somewhat slower rate than last year.
TEN years ago Lawrence Peter Berra played in his first world series. Outwardly he was the same serene person he appears to be today. Bucky Harris, his manager, gestured toward him.
ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (AP)-- Charles Howard Candler, financier and philanthropist, died today of a heart attack in Emory University Hospital. He was 78 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 --To Jason Robards Sr. the bright glare of arc lights on Warner Brothers Stage, 14 is a welcome sight, not so much because the 64-year-old actor is at work again after an eightyear layoff, but because for those years he was totally blind. Mr. Robards now has normal vision with glasses and a new career.
Four leases in the building being erected by the Seagram Company at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street, have been announced by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the new offices.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 1-- Buff Donelli of Columbia wasn't the only new head football coach in the East who got off to a fine start last week.
WHEN Gov. Luther Hartwell Hodges first took public office he was quite fond of describing himself as a "political amateur."
The formation of a nonpartisan citizens' committee to wage a campaign against the legalization of bingo was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP)--The Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment Insurance today concluded two days of meetings aimed at thrashing out disputes over jobless pay legislation.
VIENNA, Oct. 1--The first general conference of the Inter national Atomic Energy Agency opened today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1--Japan won today the seat on the Security Council that originally had been reserved for East Europe.

WORKSOP, England, Oct. 1 (UP)--The Masters champion Doug Ford, jolted the British team today by carding a 31 on the first nine of the Lindrick golf course as both Ryder Cup squads spent a long day of practice in unfamiliar sunshine.
PEIPING, Oct. 1 (Reuters)-- Communist China celebrated its eighth anniversary today with a parade of 500,000 people reviewed by Mao Tse-tung, Chief of State.
Fred Haney, the little manager of the Milwaukee Braves, has a fine proposition for Casey Stengel, his rival pilot, if Casey cares to take it up.
Despite the customary cloakand-dagger precautions that surround such things, the news somehow leaked out that the Yankees listened to scouting reports on the Milwaukee Braves yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP)--Grains and soybeans rallied on the Board of Trade today, after many futures had declined to new seasonal lows in early dealings.

Cocoa futures soared almost the daily limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The strength reflected advances in prices in London, light offerings of actuals and the belief that the market was oversold on the recent sharp declines.

A 28-year-old airman yesterday assumed leadership of the 4,000-member Flight Engineers International Association. The official, George R. Petty Jr. of Silver Springs, Md., thus became the youngest president of an international union of the merged labor movement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--A plan worked out by President Eisenhower and four Southern Governors to settle the Little Rock integration dispute broke down tonight, at least temporarily.
It will be Whitey Ford, the Yankee mound ace, against Warren Spahn, the brilliant twenty-one game winner of the Braves, in a duel of southpaws as the 1957 world series opens at the Stadium today.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 1 --Aneurin Bevan appealed to the United States today to help bring Communist China and the Soviet Union into closer relationship with the rest of the world and thus educate them to freedom.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1-- Haverford College has decided to accept no Department of Defense grants for research projects.
Bruce Moore has his feet on the ground but his imagination in the clouds in his design of five new ornamental pieces introduced this week at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 30--An electronic curtain descended around United States ships during Exercise Strike Back and virtually cut off some of the world's most powerful fighting ships from contact with Britain or the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 1--Stock market prices showed small irregular movements with leading industrials benefiting from a slackening of selling pressure. Small investment buying had erased many losses by the close.
IN the winter of 1955-56, Leon Dolice watched from his frame-shop doorway at 458 Third Avenue as wreckers tore down the rusty old elevated railroad trestle.

FIRST results of the national pheasant dog champion ship trials going on near Syracuse have been received, and it is plain that the trials have become an event of great importance to hunting dog men, amateur and professional.
City hospitals treated 2,603 new cases of upper respiratory infections between midnight Sunday and midnight Monday, the Department of Hospitals reported yesterday.
Mayor Wagner and the Democratic leadership of the City Council were accused yesterday of "deliberately stalling" consideration of the housing antibias bill until after election.

Few marketing programs spin into action as quickly as those of record companies, drive for its album from the Broadway musical "West Side Story." The show opened last Thursday to generally good reviews.
WARSAW, Oct. 1--The Polish Communist party has decided to close the crusading weekly newspaper Po Prostu. The decision is expected to be officially disclosed to the paper's editors tomorrow.

Michigan State and Minnesota moved up as chief contenders for Oklahoma's No. 1 college football position in the Associated Press weekly poll. The Sooners, idle last week, held their place atop the standing, but their margin was sharply cut by the Big Ten elevens.
The Grace Line has named Charles E. Denney as assistant to James E. Magner, executive vice president. The change was announced here yesterday by Lewis A. Lapham, president of the line.
Operating at virtually full capacity all year, the Lukens Steel Company established new records for sales and earnings in the thirty-six weeks ended Sept. 7.
IN "Escape to Adventure," Fitzroy Maclean, who commanded the British mission to the Yugoslav Partisans in World War II, gave us an unforgettable picture of that guerre a outrance.

EL DORADO, Ark., Oct. 1 (UP)--Bruce Bennett, Arkansas Attorney General, said today he thought the state constitution would have to be amended in a referendum before the Legislature could deny state tax funds to integrated schools.

ALBANY, Oct. 1--Governor Harriman announced today that he would designate Bernard Botein as Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, when Justice David W. Peck retires from that post on Dec. 31. The appointment was forecast yesterday.

Never before have the nation's big bond houses had for sale such an assortment of topname corporate securities at generous new-issue yields as now. These yields generally run to a substantial fraction of 1 percentage point above those obtainable from similar seasoned issues in the secondary market.
ROME, Oct. 1--Pieces of smaller marble statues have been brought to light in the cave at Sperlonga where more than 400 fragments of a Laocoon were discovered a few days ago.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 1-- Reed's Knight, the 5-to-4 favorite, scored a half-length victory in the featured $4,500 Old Westbury Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The 5-year-old bay horse, owned by the Happy Valley Stock Farm of Suffolk, Va., was driven by James Arthur.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 1 --Taft School's football linemen --some thirty strong--trooped into the medieval civilization classroom early tonight to take in the movies of last Saturday's 13-all game with Kingswood. The backs are scheduled to do the same thing tomorrow.
The State of New York borrowed $24,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of mental treatment institutions.

The sports car racing year is nearing its end. It has been a year of tremendous growth and advancement. The importation of fast and expensive equipment reached a new high. Our racing drivers have increased in number and many new stars have emerged.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--With none of the ballyhoo surrounding this season's debuts of 1958 model automobiles, the Treasury today introduced its 1957 model dollar bill.

TO see "Look Back in Anger" at the Lyceum, where it opened last evening, is to agree with the British who saw the original performance. John Osborne has written the most vivid British play of the decade.

An unusually warm September held sales of major department stores in the metropolitan area an average of 0.5 per cent lower than in the 1956 month, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

GENEVA, Oct. 1--Foreign Minister Max Petitpierre said in Bern today that Switzerland would bring suit against the United States in the International Court of Justice for return of the General Aniline and Film Corporation to its former owners.

BATON ROUGE, Oct. 1 (AP)-- Louisiana plans no further reduction in crude oil production despite a 5 per cent cut in purchasing by the Esso Standard Oil Company, an affilate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- Spokesmen for the New York Power Authority told the Federal Power Commission today that changes in proposed engineering plans for the Niagara power project could increase costs by as much as $207,000,000.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 1 (UP) --Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo said today the United States would continue to win friends in Asia and Africa if it matched ideals with deeds.

HERALDED by two gallery exhibitions last week, the tidal invasion of twentiethcentury German art that promises to leave its impression on this season rises sharply this week. The central event is the comprehensive survey of paintings, ...
Buff Donelli of Columbia wasn't the only Ivy League coach to be stirred by parental pride last Saturday.

LONDON, Sept. 24--Playing an important role in the forthcoming state visit will be two of Queen Elizabeth's ladiesin-waiting, the Countess of Leicester and Lady Rose Baring. There may well be a spare one on tap, but these two are long experienced and tops at their jobs.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1-- There is no place for hospital changes to go these days but up, hospital officials said here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)-- Ezra Taft Benson said today that the National Agricultural Advisory Commission wanted the Eisenhower Administration to press Congress for authority to provide lower price supports for surplus crops.
Plans are being formulated for the third annual Heart of America Ball, which will be be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on April 29.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1-- King Hussein of Jordan personally faced down his antiWestern Parliament today with a slashing attack on the Leftist Cabinet he ousted last April.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--Two of the Southern Governors trying to negotiate the withdrawal of troops from Little Rock with President Eisenhower took a hopeful attitude in a television interview late last night.

Yesterday in Vienna there took place the opening meeting of the General Conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency. U.N. Secretary General Hammarskjold, who had hoped to be present, sent to this meeting a message to be read for him by Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 1 --Gov. Orval E. Faubus was silent tonight after President Eisenhower rejected temporarily his promise to abide by the arrangements worked out today in Washington for a solution of the Little Rock integration crisis.
THE Philadelphia Orchestra has become the early bird. It begins its home season ahead of New York's orchestra, and in recent years it has been the ensemble to launch the new symphonic season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1-- An expansion of the faculty and curriculum of Dropsie College was announced here tonight. The announcement was made by Dr. Abraham A. Neuman, president, at exercises inaugurating the fifty-first year of the college.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- Chief Justice Earl Warren ruled today that the Teamsters Union could elect officers at its national convention, now in session at Miami.
Two young Brooklyn men were arraigned yesterday in Adolescent Court and charged with robbing and beating the Nepalese Ambassador to the United Nations last month.
A brief strike that closed 278 newsstands and luncheonettes here was settled yesterday. Stands in hotels, subways, office buildings and rail, bus and ferry terminals were affected.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 6 to 17 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday.
New mechanical developments and a growing emphasis on fashion are expanding watch band sales.

VOUILLE, France, Sept. 23-- The spectacular results achieved here by Paul Savariau with a combination of brains, technical knowledge and hard work seem to refute pessimistic assertions that the small family farm is no longer viable in France.
The Dodger baseball club probably will remain in Brooklyn for at least two weeks more.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday a series of changes in high executive posts. Ralph J. Cordiner, president, said they were designed "to meet the growing needs of the company."
The most promising attempt to end the Algerian revolt has come to naught and France is again in the midst of a Cabinet crisis.
DETROIT, Oct. 1--Oldsmobile's lowest-priced 1958 model will sacrifice horsepower for fuel economy, Jack F. Wolfram, general manager, said today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 1-- Nassau County detectives began a widespread search today for the mother and former wife of a 41-year-old airplane parts manufacturer who was murdered last night in his West Hempstead factory.
Ownership of the thirtythree-year-old publishing house of Simon Schuster, Inc., has been taken over jointly by M. Lincoln Schuster and Leon Shimkin.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 1-- Former Field Marshal Ferdinand Schoerner, once known as Hitler's most fanatical general, Stood before the Munich Assize Court today charged with homicide and attempted homicide.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- Americans for Democratic Action said today that nine Democratic senators had a 100 per cent "liberal quotient" voting record in the recent session of Congress.
A nine-member Board of Correction was appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The board was created under legislation signed by the Mayor last June 5.
TRENTON, Oct. 1--State Senator James F. Murray Jr. and his adherents withdrew their insurgent slate of Democratic candidates in Hudson County today.
PARIS, Oct. 1--President Rene Coty, who remains in office while French Governments come and go, began today to pick up the pieces of the one smashed by the National Assembly last night.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP)-- The criminal libel conspiracy trial of Confidential magazine ended today with the jury split 7--5 for conviction.
Negotiations for the sale of television station WATV (Channel 13) to National Telefilm Associates, Inc., reportedly have been terminated, at least for the time being.

The meeting of the four Southern Governors with the President yesterday resulted in new declarations that, despite their obvious loopholes; raised hopes at first that a solution of the Little Rock crisis might be on the way. But the plans for a settlement collapsed owing to the extraordinary stubbornness of Governor Faubus.
TRENTON, Oct. 1--Last spring's vast spray operation against the tree-destroying gypsy moth in northern New Jersey has been pronounced a "complete success."
Mrs. Caroline K. Simon called yesterday for a two-pronged investigation of the city's school system.

Darubini, owned by Mrs. Henry T. McKnight, won the $17,250 Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The victory, though was one of adjudication rather than competition. The Tower Hill Farm's Langton Breeze finished first, but was disqualified and placed last.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 1--The machine behind James R. Hoffa is as efficient and wellheeled as any at a national political convention.
BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 1 (Reuters)--Switzerland conceded today that foreign embassies and legations were subjected to wiretapping, but insisted it was legal under Swiss law.
Our congratulations go to State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein on his appointment as Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First District.
Jack Soble, admitted spy for the Soviet Union, said yesterday that he deeply regretted his past and the crimes he had committed against this country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- Rockets that explode "firecracker" grenades in their ascent have shown that winter winds high over the Arctic blow at 335 miles an hour.
The stock market yesterday made its best gain since Sept. 12 but made it in an irregular fashion. Every major group had losses as well as advances.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage unless specified.
Stocks pushed upward yesterday on unimportant volume The best gains appeared steels, metals, rails, chemicals rubbers, business machines an public utilities. Aircrafts were soft.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 2--Acting Premier Ferenc Munnich indicated today that his Government would be receptive to specific proposals concerning Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

THE wisdom of the National Broadcasting Com pany in trying to televise the world series in color must be questioned, particularly in view of the added problems created by the early October shadows over the playing field at Yankee Stadium.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 2--The Rev. Joseph A. Farrell, former treasurer and spiritual director of Georgetown University, died here yesterday at St. Francis Hospital. His age was 81.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2-- Two days of assorted civic activities and much hobnobbing of local citizens with Hollywood stars came to a climax here this evening with a Kentuckyflavored world premiere of the movie. "Raintree County."

THE curtain rises this week on the "Second Act." This shop for "outgrown" but not "out-worn" children's clothes has been plotted for years by Mrs. Sayre MacLeod, a trim, thin woman with hornrimmed goggles and discreet diamonds.

Dr. Sophie Rabinoff of 166 East Ninety-sixth Street, who retired in June, 1956, as Professor of Public Health and Industrial Medicine at New York Medical College of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals died at the hospital yesterday. Her age was 68.
The curtain rose on the 1957 world series at the Stadium yesterday with at least half the cast brand new. But there still was no change in a long familiar script.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Sept. 25;
Three members of Congress joined with representatives of industry urging tax relief for small business, yesterday in a hearing before the Senate Select Committee on Small Business.
Robert K. Christenberry proposed yesterday that New York City coordinate its expenditures for housing, schools, playgrounds and other improvements to create balanced neighborhoods within the city.

Fifth Avenue is being beautified right down to its trash cans. The Fifth Avenue Association, with the help of the Sanitation Department, began lining the famous street yesterday with 250 golden trash cans.
The trial of Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel, accused as a spy for the Soviet Union, will start this morning in the Federal Court, Brooklyn.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 2 (Reuters)--Five days of medical examination in the United States military hospital here have revealed no trace of poison in the system of Nikolai Khokhlov, former Soviet secret police captain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The State Department has accused the Haitian police of murdering a United States citizen. The man had been given into their custody for questioning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The coming visit of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip has produced briefings about procedures and protocol.
Tightness of the mortgage money market has forced Vincent Astor to seek new equity capital to finance the blocksquare Astor Plaza building on Park Avenue.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2-- Extensive Federal assistance to hospitals was requested today by the American Hospital Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Secretary of State Dulles will meet Saturday with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to talk over issues dividing the United States and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--A Federal Power Commission hearing on engineering features of the Niagara power project bogged down today in legal arguments.
TOKYO, Oct. 2 (Reuters)-- Japanese shipbuilders have developed new construction methods said to reduce building time by a quarter.
LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP)-- Billing Bear, owned by Mrs. Cordelia S. May of Pittsbrugh and ridden by Jimmy Murphy, won the $2,500 Rolling Rock Hunt Cup over a two-mile steeplechase course today.
Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, said here yesterday that the 1958 league schedule made no provision for a New York baseball team.

IN Cambodia, not long ago, Santha Rama Rau was a guest at a royal party. One of the King's ministers turned to her, gestured toward the sovereign in his white and gold uniform, the assembled diplomats in quaint costumes of European courts, the royal dancers energetically at work, and asked: "Do you have such ceremonies in...
MOSCOW, Oct. 1--Wanted: Some good, dignified, harmonious, melodic, genteel jazz, Russian jazz.
PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 3--A 29-year-old French woman gave birth yesterday to quintuplets. Early today two of the five infants had died and fears were expressed for the others.

To mix business with pleasure, a word about baseball bats: Mickey Mantle is using a bat thirty-five inches long and weighing thirty-four ounces; Yogi Berra one of the same length, but weighing thirtythree ounces. On the Milwaukee
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The Soviet Union was reported today to be working on plans to photograph the sun's corona from its projected artificial moons.
DETROIT, Oct. 2--American Motors Corporation will concentrate on "compact and common-sense transportation" in its 1958 models, George Romney, president of the company, said today.

Speaking broadly, it may be said that the fundamental objective of the credit restraint policies of the nation's monetary authorities has been to hold the rate of economic expansion within the limits set by the public's saving and increased productivity. In other words, it has
Coffee futures dropped yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The decline accompanied a reduction in the wholesale prices of most nationally advertised vacuumpacked coffees.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2--The redevelopment of a small part of Westchester County's overburdened parkway between New York City and Connecticut will begin sooner than officials had expected. If weather permits, power shovels should be on the job in January. The project is located in Harrison.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 2 (AP) --Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland today accused Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas of "double-crossing" the four Southern Governors who met ...
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1-- There's a grim sort of India to be seen and listened to these days in the offices of New Delhi's massive Government buildings.

Sales of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., for the fiscal year ended June 30 were the highest in its twenty-nineyear history, J.W. Schwab, president, told stockholders yesterday in the annual report. Mr. Schwab, said, however, that earnings declined as a result of severe competition.

A detective's sixth sense, developed during his years on the police force, enabled the general counsel of the Transit Authority this week to solve the mystery of a subway crash in which a motorman was killed.
CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 2 -- Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, defended the use of Federal troops in the Little Rock school integration crisis in a speech today to Southern Republican leaders.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The president of the New York Stock Exchange urged today a lowering "in the near future" of the present 70 per cent margin requirement on stocks to a "normal 40 to 50 per cent."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Prospects for better nutrition and more normal child growth in the tropics were cited today by a New York physician who is now serving as medical adviser to the Haitian Government.

PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 2-- The defending champion, Frederick J. Wright, a 59-year-old investment broker from Watertown, Mass., gained the quarter-final round today in the United States Golf Association senior championship. He defeated New Jersey's last remaining competitor, Paul A. Dunkel of the host club, 3 and 2.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP)--Improved demand for grains and soybeans lifted most futures prices on the Board of Trade today.

The annual autumn benefit of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church will be held Oct. 22 in the recreation hall of the church at Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street. This year's event will be a tea and fashion show.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 2--Syracuse last season had one of the best pairs of halfbacks to wear the Orange in many years in Jim Brown and Jim Ridlon.
PARIS, Oct, 2--Rene Pleven, a former Premier, was regarded tonight as the man most likely to be asked to form a new French Government. M. Pleven, who is 56 years old, has held the office twice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 --A second movie about the career, of P.T. Barnum--this one to be a full-fledged biographical drama--was scheduled today for production by the new independent firm of Jurow-Shepherd Productions.
World series fame is "old hat" to Whitey Ford and Jerry Coleman, the co-heroes of the Yankees' triumph over the Braves yesterday.
FRANK GOAD CLEMENT is a Bible-quoting Southerner. He says that he does not like to see whites and Negroes mix in schools.
Merchant marine officers manned picket lines at Bull Line piers yesterday to contime without interruption a tie-up that began forty-six days ago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 2-- Israel's wandering Philharmonic Orchestra dedicated its permanent home here tonight with a program by an extraordinary array of musical talent before an unusual international audience.
Hisato Ichimada, Japan's Finance Minister, who describes himself as a "realistic optimist," predicts that his nation will recover from a sharp imbalance of its foreign trade.
New issues of corporate preferred stock and debt securities totaling $37,500,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates as follows:
TRENTON, Oct. 2--The Republican-controlled State Legislature was accused today of having spent $42,395 for food and motel accommodations in violation of the state Constitution and an executive order.

VIENNA, Oct. 2--Two Soviet attempts to have Communist China admitted to the International Atomic Energy Agency were defeated today. The agency is holding its first General conference on use of atoms for peace.

The mounting national concern with labors misdeeds has moved Boyd Leedom, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, to a public explanation of what the board "can do about the racket union and the unscrupulous employer." In his

Dr. Louis Anthony Bonvicino of 1815 Eighty-second Street, Brooklyn, a retired neuropsychiatrist, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, after a short illness. His age was 68.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 2 --Hugh Gaitskell won a decisive victory today for Labor's new modified policy on public ownership. The victory solidified his position as leader of a united and powerful party.

Sal Maglie pitched batting practice for the Yankees before yesterday's world series opener. Then, ineligible to face the Braves because he had not joined the Bombers until Sept. 1, he retired to the stands and watched the game from a back row of the auxiliary press box.
REVOLUTIONARIES in Paris and New York are girding their cutting boards and sewing machines for the greatest dressmaking upheaval in years. The war cry is "chemise."
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh rejected yesterday a request from a deputy Fire Commissioner to invalidate a traffic ticket issued to a Municipal Court justice.

SATURDAY, 11 A.M. and 1:30 P.M.: Three films, "Toccata for Toy Train," "Carmen" and "Corral" will be shown to youngsters free at the Museum of the City of New York. The program is for children 4 to 8 years old, Miss Janet Pinney, Supervisor of the Educational Department will also tell stories. For information call LEhigh 4-1672.
At world series time everyone, it appears, is a critic. Whitey Ford, who went all the way and beat the Braves in yesterday's opener, called his five-hit performance "spotty."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The State Department refused formal comment today on the announcement yesterday in Bern that Switzerland would sue in the International Court of Justice for return of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.
The arrest of three men accused of being members of a gang that robbed three New Jersey banks of $56,000 between last May and August was announced yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WILTON, Conn., Oct. 2--The Wilton Historical Society is again aroused over the disrepute to which street naming has fallen in this 256-year-old community.
WORKSOP, England, Oct. 2 (UP)--Mrs. Janet Sidda, who does not like golf, is forcing the Ryder Cup matches to open on, a shortened course Friday.

The men who guide the destinies of the open-end investment companies are not at all bearish in the present market. It may be wrong to say that they are bullish; some are not. But none could be classed as bearish.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 2 --Gov. Orval E. Faubus stood firm today against President Eisenhower. He said he would proceed in his own fashion to enforce court orders on school integration once Federal troops were removed.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 2--A new film society, formed by two enterprising Norwalk commuters, will get under way next week. Named Connecticut Cine 16, it is a nonprofit organization that will present Sundaynight showings of motion-picture classics.

CASEY STENGEL had his Ouija board jumping like crazy for the opening game of the world series at the Stadium yesterday. The old master of the black arts was at his occult best and all the answers were supplied to him. Since he couldn't make a mistake, the Yankees beat the Braves with startling simplicity.

President Eisenhower's steps to uphold Federal law in the integration dispute in Little Rock, Ark., were commended yesterday by the general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

Mrs. Ethel Jacobs' Promised Land took the $28,850 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday. With Hedley Woodhouse doing a fine job of steering, the son of Palestinian closed fast to beat Assemblyman by a half-length in the test of a mile and five-eighths. Jocko's Walk was third.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)-- James B. Carey told James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, today the Eisenhower Administration, and not organized labor, was responsible for what Mr. Carey termed an inadequate civil rights bill.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 2--If the Choate School is not represented by a well-drilled football squad this season it's not going to be the fault of Coach Jack Davison and his capable staff.

Overflow crowds of world series fans are going as far as Greenwich, Conn.--thirty-five miles from New York City--to obtain hotel accommodations. Other fans have obtained accommodations in Garden City, L.I., and Newark, N.J.
The Florida Railroad and Public Utilities Commission sought yesterday to convince the financial community that it had not suddenly turned into an anti-utility monster.

The Long Island sector of the Professional Golfers Association will close the tournament year Monday with the customary district championship at the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Great Neck. After the competition the players will gather for a dinner at which Al Ciuci, the organization's president, will preside.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 2-- Flashing past horses in the final sixteenth, the Gray Brothers Maxine's Knight from East Providence, R.I., scored a onelength victory over Easter Dawn in the Lawrence Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UP)--Yama Bahama upset Del Flanagan tonight, gaining a unanimous tenround decision in a televised bout at Chicago Stadium.

Miss Suzannah Van Vlaanderen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius H. Van Vlaanderen of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., will be presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the V'aldorf-Astoria on Dec. 20.
SAN MARINO, Oct. 2--A few scattered rifle shots and bursts of submachine gun fire shattered the quiet of this tiny state today.

EVERY time some notable fishing community joins the growing movement for the release of captured game fish the health of sports fishing gets a little stronger. Now it is Bermuda, and more power to the elbow of its Fishing Information Bureau.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct 2 (AP) -- Two newspaper men, four suspended county policemen and a former police chief were among twelve persons indicted today by the Jefferson County grand jury. It had been investigating alleged irregularities in the county patrol.

Steps are being taken by Meyer Levin, author of "Compulsion" and adapter of the best-seller for the stage, to prevent the opening of what he asserts is an unauthorized version on Oct. 21 at the Ambassador Theatre. The drama,
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)-- The continuing squeeze of rising costs on profits was reflected in a report issued today by the Federal Trade Commission.
"Miss Lonelyhearts," a new play by Howard Teichmann from the novel of the same name by the late Nathanael West, will have its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Music Box.

ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (UP)-- Gov. Marvin Griffin of Georgia said today President Eisenhower set out on a "desperate and very danerous course" in the Little Rock integration turmoil in an attempt to "force" Vice President Richard M. Nixon into the White House.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., Oct. 2-- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association team defeated a team from the Garden State Golf Association today.
ALBANY, Oct. 2--Business men came to the capital today to deplore the "phony bargain," but few of them wanted the state to do anything about it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2-- Charles E. Wilson announced today a decision by the Air Force to limit payments temporarily to major aircraft contractors regardless of the size of the bills they present to the Government.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu said today that plotters against his revolutionary Argentine regime were like "hens sitting on china eggs."
